Socialist Republic of Viet Nam

Project Description

Classification

Primary objective: Poverty reduction

Environmental
Assessment

Rationale

The Project will assist the Government's efforts to reduce poverty by
promoting  private  sector  investments  in  micro  and  small  rural
enterprises through (i) the provision of medium- and long-term credit;
and  (ii)  strengthening  the  operations  of  the  Viet  Nam  Bank  for
Agriculture  and  Rural  Development  (VBARD),  and  the  Central
People's Credit Fund (CCF) and its member People's Credit Funds
(PCFs).

Category B
An  initial  environmental  examination  was  undertaken  and  the
summary is a core appendix.

Although Viet Nam is resource rich and its labor force is among the
most  competitive  in  Asia,  insufficient  private  investment  in  support
services  and  lack  of  financial  services  are  among  the  biggest
constraints  that  prevent  it  from  fully  exploiting  its  advantages.  The
lack  of  fund  resources  and  the  paucity  of  medium-  and  long-term
capital  are  major  constraints  to  the  growth  of  rural  household  and
micro  and  small-scale  businesses.  By  promoting  the  establishment
of  value-added  enterprises,  rural  households  and  businesses  can
raise the productivity of land and labor.

The  earlier  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)-financed  Rural  Credit
Project (RCP)1 has shown that the demand for this type of credit is
strong,  and  the  loan  has  improved  the  incomes  of  subborrowers
formal
and  created  employment  opportunities.  Although 
financial  system  reaches  50  percent  of  rural  households,  it  has
bypassed  about  6  million  poorer  households.  As  major  lenders  to
the  poor,  VBARD  and  PCFs  have  developed  the  infrastructure  to
reach  poor  households  and  are  the  most  appropriate  and  cost-
efficient  institutions  to  extend  financial  services  to  those  not
covered  so  far,  as  well  as  to  check  the  growing  disparity  in  rural-
urban incomes.

mismatch  in  their  sources  and  the  duration  of  their  funds,  and
through  the  loan's  selective  and  leveraged  financing,  assist  in
the
achieving  ADB’s  strategic  objectives  and 
effectiveness of its assistance.

Objectives and Scope

The  Project  aims  to  support  the  Government’s  efforts  to  reduce
poverty  and  promote  private  sector  investments  in  rural  and  agro-

                                                
1 Loan 1457-VIE:Rural Credit Project, for $50.0 million, approved on 12  September 1996.

 iii

based  businesses  through  credit.  The  scope  comprises  (i)  a  credit
line  to  VBARD  to  finance  about  14,900  micro  and  small  rural
enterprises  (MSEs) and 18,500 income-generating activities of low-
income households; (ii) a credit line to CCF to finance 7,500 MSEs
and  31,000  income-generating  activities  of  low-income  households;
and  (iii)  strengthening  the  capacity  of  VBARD  and  CCF-PCF  in
providing efficient and improved services to rural clients. The Project
will  be  implemented  in  the  rural  areas  whose  economic  roles  and
functions  are  closely  linked  to  agricultural  and  rural  enterprises,
outside the municipal boundaries of Hanoi and Ho Chi Minh cities.
Areas designated as the poorest in the country will receive special
consideration  to  narrow  the  gap  in  incomes  and  to  attain  sectoral
and regional balance in growth.

The total cost of the Project is estimated at $145.5 million equivalent
of  which  $60.9  million  equivalent  is  the  foreign  exchange  cost  and
$84.6 million equivalent is the local currency cost.

Total Cost

A loan of Special Drawing Rights 62,532,000 ($80 million equivalent)
will  be  made  from  ADB’s  Special  Funds  resources  and  will  have  a
term  of  32  years,  including  a  grace  period  of  8  years.  An  interest
charge of 1 percent will be levied on the loan during the grace period
and 1.5 percent during the amortization period.  ADB will finance 55
percent of the cost of each subproject, VBARD and PCF will finance
31 percent, and the subborrowers will fund the balance (14 percent)
from their own resources.

The  Government  will  relend  the  loan  proceeds  in  dong  to  VBARD
and  CCF  at  the  weighted  average  cost  of  deposit  funds  of  the
banking system, determined by the State Bank of Viet Nam (SBV) at
the end of each quarter. VBARD  will onlend to eligible subborrowers
at  a  market  interest  rate  based  on  a  margin  not  exceeding  3.6
percent  for  short-term  loans  and  6.0  percent  for  medium-  and  long-
term loans above the average prime rate of nine commercial banks
determined  by  SBV  on  a  monthly  basis.  It  is  envisaged  that  this
market rate will cover operating costs, loan losses, interest variation
risks, and a reasonable profit for VBARD. CCF-PCF will onlend at a
rate  currently  set  at  14  percent  by  SBV;  that  will  cover  operating
costs,  loan  losses,  interest  variation  risks,  and  a  reasonable  profit.

Implementation
Arrangements

iv

For VBARD, up to 65 percent of the credit line may be subloans to
small  enterprises  (less  than  50  employees).  The  subloans  will  not
exceed $30,000 equivalent, and on average will be about $7,500. At
least  15  percent  of  subloans  by  value  will  be  made  to  micro
enterprises  (less  than  5  employees)  and  20  percent  to  low-income
households  with  a  per  capita  expenditure  of  $128  per  annum.  For
PCF, subloans will not exceed $10,000 equivalent, and will average
about  $750  made  to  micro  businesses.  At  least  50  percent  of
subloans by value will be made to low-income households with a per
capita  expenditure  of  $128  per  annum.  The  repayment  and  grace
periods  will  be  based  on  the  cash  flow  of  the  subprojects  and  the
repayment capacity of the subborrowers.

Suitably  equipped  and  staffed  project  implementation  units  (PIUs)
will  be  established  in  VBARD  and  the  CCF.  The  PIU  will  be  the
project-specific  contact  and  focal  point  on  all  matters  relating  to
implementation, management, and coordination of the Project. The
following  organizational  units  of  VBARD  and  CCF  will  participate
directly  in  project  activities:  (i)  the  Credit  Department  in  the  head
office;  (ii)  the  concerned  provincial  and  district  branches  or  PCFs;
(iii)  the  Training  Division  at  head  office;  and  (iv)  the  Planning  and
Budget  Division,  which  will  coordinate  with  all  divisions  and
departments concerned on project implementation.

To ensure effective coordination and supervision, the SBV will act
as  a  project  coordination  agency  responsible  for  implementing
policy aspects of the Project, overseeing the implementation of the
reform  action  plans  of  VBARD  and  CCF-PCF,  and  ensuring
compliance by VBARD and CCF-PCF with all covenants in the loan
and  project  agreements.  In  addition,  the  Government  will  form  a
project  steering  committee  headed  by  a  deputy  governor  of  SBV,
which will meet at least twice yearly to provide overall guidance and
directions  for  project  implementation,  and  help  to  resolve  any
outstanding issues.

Project benefits and
Beneficiaries

31 May 2006

The Project will result in increased income for about 72,000 farmers,
farm households, and rural businesses. Of this, 49,500 low-income
households  (below  the  poverty  line)  or  70  percent  of  project
beneficiaries  will  benefit  from  financial  assistance,  and  600  micro
and  small  businesses  will  be  assisted  with  support  services  from
rural business centers. About 101,700 full-time jobs will be created.
By creating remunerative employment in the rural areas; assisting in
establishing  new  enterprises;  and  expanding,  modernizing,  and
balancing existing enterprises, the Project will improve the dispersal
of  economic  activities  to  the  rural  areas,  thereby  helping  to  narrow
the  income  gap  between  rural  and  urban  households.  The  Project
will  contribute  to  strengthening  the  rural  skills  base,  as  well  as
linkages  with  the  urban  economy  by  supporting  the  creation  of
sustainable  rural  business  centers  (RBCs),  which  will  provide
business advisory and training services, among others, in rural areas
on a commercial basis.

Although  the  Government  has  further  liberalized  interest  rate  by
introducing  a  base  lending  rate  on  a  monthly  basis,  being  the
average  rate  for  the  prime  customers  of  the  main  commercial
banks operating in the country, VBARD and CCF are not permitted
to charge interest on their subloans beyond the margin prescribed
by  the  Government,  currently  0.5  percent  per  month  for  medium-
and long-term loans. Under the circumstances, there is a risk that
VBARD  and  CCF-PCF  may  not  earn  enough  to  cover  the  cost  of
their  rural  lending.  Also,  commercial  credit  risks  resulting  from
adverse  weather  conditions,  poor  markets,  poor  infrastructure,
insufficient collateral, etc., are associated with all subloans. These
risks  are  expected  to  be  mitigated  with,  among  others,  an  annual
review of the adequacy of spreads for delivering financial services
(and  appropriate  changes  made  on  them),  training  of  credit  staff,
introduction  of  an  incentive  system  based  on  subloan  recovery
performance,  improved  monitoring  systems,  and  establishment  of
RBCs to assist and advise subborrowers.

To  help  Viet  Nam  create  sustainable  support  services  for  nonfarm
and  rural  businesses,  the  Government  requested  a  technical
assistance  (TA)  to  (i)  establish  three  pilot  RBCs,  which  will  provide
credit  facilitation,  business  advisory  and  training  services,  among

 vii

 I. 

THE PROPOSAL

1.
I submit for your approval the following Report and Recommendation on a proposed loan
to  the  Socialist  Republic  of  Viet  Nam  for  the  Rural  Enterprise  Finance  Project.  The  Report  also
describes  proposed  technical  assistance  (TA)  for  Support  for  Rural  Businesses,  and  if  the
proposed  loan  is  approved  by  the  Board,  I,  acting  under  the  authority  delegated  to  me  by  the
Board, shall approve the TA.

II. 

INTRODUCTION

At the request of the Government, a Loan Appraisal Mission1 from the Asian Development
2.
Bank (ADB) visited Viet Nam from 16 to 28 August 2000 to process the Rural Enterprise Finance
Project.  The  Mission  met  staff  of  various  Government  departments,  State  Bank  of  Viet  Nam
(SBV),  Viet  Nam  Bank  for  Agriculture  and  Rural  Development  (VBARD),  the  Central  People’s
Credit Fund-People’s Credit Fund (CCF-PCF), and beneficiaries under the Rural Credit Project2 to
discuss  the  formulation  and  implementation  arrangements  for  the  Project.  The  Project  first
appeared  in  ADB’s  Country  Assistance  Program  (CAP)  in  December  1997.  A  Mission3  to
prepare a project in 1998 identified some financial and institutional weaknesses in VBARD and
agreed with the VBARD to address these weaknesses through an advisory technical assistance
(ADTA)4  before  another  loan  was  provided.  The  TA  commenced  in  January  2000  and  is
expected  to  be  completed  early  in  2001.  The  TA  progress  to  date  is  such  that  ADB  is
proceeding  with  processing  the  proposed  Project.  An  ADB  Country  Programming  Mission  in
March  2000  confirmed  that  the  Project  will  be  processed  for  approval  by  ADB  in  2000.  The
project framework is in Appendix 1.

3.
The operations of ADB in Viet Nam have focused on supporting the country’s transition to
a  market-based  economy.  Central  to  the  operations  is  assistance  with  policy  reforms  in  the
agriculture and financial sectors, expanding rural enterprise and nonfarm businesses through the
development of rural financial institutions, and priority programs for poverty reduction in the rural
sector.  In September 1996, ADB approved a loan of SDR34.1 million to the Government for the
Rural  Credit  Project  (RCP)  to  finance  short-  and  medium-term  loans  for  agriculture  and
agribusinesses and to strengthen rural financial institutions. Because of the very strong demand
for such credit, the loan amount was nearly fully disbursed by June 2000. In view of the positive
impact  on  rural  incomes  and  employment,  and  the  performance  of  the  participating  financial
institutions  the  Government  requested  ADB  for  a  follow-on  project  to  further  strengthen  the
capacity of VBARD and the CCF-PCF network.

III.

BACKGROUND

The Government of Viet Nam's economic development strategy since 1986 has been doi
4.
moi:  a  reform  process  to  transform  the  economy  from  central  planning  to  free  market.  In
1992/93, 51 percent of the population were classified as poor based on a poverty line equivalent
to 13 kilograms (kg) of rice per capita per month.5 Viet Nam currently has a per capita income of
about $350 per annum. Recent research shows that 20 percent of the population remained very

to  PRC  Director;  and  J.  T.  F.  Choong,  Consultant.  J.  Wynne-Williams,  Consultant  on  TA  3227-VIE  assisted  the
Mission.

 2

poor (with less than $0.50 per capita per day), while nearly 50 percent (about 40 million people)
are below the international dollar per day poverty line.6 There are significant regional as well as
urban  and  rural  differences  in  the  incidence  of  poverty  in  Viet  Nam.  According  to  the  Viet  Nam
Living  Standards  Survey  (1993),  90  percent  of  the  poor  are  found  among  three  quarters  of  the
population  living  in  rural  areas,  indicating  disproportionate  rural  impoverishment.  With  the  vastly
different growth rates from 2.5 percent in the North and central region to 15 percent in the South,
this income disparity between rural and urban sector workers is set to widen. Between 1993 and
1998, the ratio of the expenditure of the top 20 percent and the bottom 20 percent rose from 4.9 to
5.5.

5.
The  impact  of  the  recent  strong  economic  growth  on  rural  employment  generation  and
on farmers income has been limited. While the transition to a market economy is improving the
livelihoods of many, it is also creating a large pool of poor families that lack resources and are
vulnerable  to  economic  shocks,  which  were  previously  mitigated  by  the  cooperative  system
safety net. Among them are women and minority groups who bear particularly heavy adjustment
costs (as Viet Nam moves away from the centralized system) and whose lives are so precarious
that  it  only  takes  an  unforeseen  crisis  such  as  ill  health  to  set  in  motion  a  downward  spiral  in
their  standard  of  living.  Their  vulnerability  is  compounded  by  their  lack  of  access  to  financial
resources and their inability to borrow sufficient amounts from formal sources because of supply
and collateral constraints.

6.
The Government recognizes the importance of small and medium-scale enterprises and
their  significance  in  the  market  economies  of  other  countries  in  the  region.7  Overall,  it  is
estimated  that  about  10  million  workers  are  unemployed.  In  urban  areas,  the  unemployment
rate varies between 4.6 and 7.3 percent.  8 Underemployment is estimated to be 26 percent in
rural areas and 17 percent in urban areas. There are about 1 million new entrants to the labor
force  each  year.  It  is  recognized  that  the  agriculture  sector  is  unlikely  to  generate  significant
increases in employment opportunities and the focus is now on the creation of employment in
rural industry and services as the main means of economic growth and reducing poverty.

7.
However,  despite  the  recognition  of  the  need  for  an  environment  in  which  private  rural
enterprise  can  flourish,  Government  policies  have  to  some  extent  hindered  its  creation,  and
reform  is  necessary.  Recent  changes  in  the  enterprise  law  have  reduced  the  bureaucracy
involved in business establishment, but high marginal tax rates on income and enterprise profits
discourage  entrepreneurship,  inhibit  employment  creation,  and  encourage  tax  evasion.  Tax
incentives for small businesses merit more consideration because it is small businesses that will
primarily address the severe rural underemployment problem.

A. 

Sector Description

1. 

Financial Sector

8.
The Vietnamese financial system comprises the formal, semiformal, and informal sector.
The formal financial sector comprises three groups of financial institutions operating under the

 3

prudential  supervision  of  SBV:  banks,  finance  companies,  and  cooperatives.  The  institutional
structure, as of 30 June 2000, consisted of (i) State Bank of Viet Nam (Central Bank); (ii) State-
owned  commercial  banks  (Bank  for  Foreign  Trade  of  Viet  Nam,  Bank  of  Investment  and
Development of Viet Nam, Industrial and Commercial Bank of Viet Nam, VBARD, and Viet Nam
Bank  for  the  Poor  [VBP];  (iii)  68  foreign  banks  of  which  29  have  branches;  (iv)  two  finance
companies; (v) four joint-venture banks; (vi) 16 insurance companies, (vii) 50 joint-stock banks
(31 urban and 19 rural); (viii) 960 PCFs (and an apex CCF); and (ix) 69 credit cooperatives.

The Government is pursuing a banking reform program comprising (i) restructuring joint-
9.
stock  banks  and  State-owned  commercial  banks  (SOCBs);  (ii)  improving  the  regulatory,
supervisory, and legal framework; and (iii) developing human resources in the banking sector.  In
the  near  term  the  agenda  of  the  reform  program  includes  (i)  restructuring  plans  for  SOCBs;  (ii)
issuance  of  a  decree  to  limit  policy-induced  lending;  (iii)  establishing  an  asset  management
company; (iv) rehabilitating joint sector banks; (v) moving toward a risk-based supervision system;
and (vi) deregulating the administrative interest rate structure. The International Monetary Fund's
(IMF) Enhanced Structural Adjustment Fund (ESAF) and Poverty Reduction and Growth Facility
(PRGF),  World  Bank’s  Structural  Adjustment  Credit,  ADB’s  Financial  Sector  Program  Loan
(FSPL)  and  Corporate  Governance  TA,  and  bilateral  sources  are  supporting  these  reform
measures.

Progress has been made in (i) restructuring joint-stock banks and SOCBs; (ii) improving

2.

Rural Financial Sector

11.
Two  rural  SOCBs  (VBARD  and  VBP),  19  rural  shareholding  banks,  960  PCFs,  and  69
credit cooperatives service the agriculture and rural sector, reaching 6 million people or about
50  percent  of  rural  farm  households.  Among  them,  VBARD,  the  premier  agricultural  and  rural
development  bank,  has  a  market  share  of  3.7  million  rural  households.  VBARD  has  also  the
largest  lending  volume,  with  75  percent  of  the  total  lending  to  the  sector  in  1999  or  D32,000
billion  (about  $2.286  billion),  PCFs  provide  about  5  percent  and  nongovernment  organizations
(NGOs),  a  negligible  share.  VBARD  lends  to  farm  households,  cooperatives,  and  private
commercial and State-owned enterprises (SOEs). Loans to SOEs constitute about 30 percent of
VBARD’s  total  loans  outstanding.  It  is  estimated  that  15-20  percent  of  these  loans  are
delinquent.  Loans  to  private  enterprises  constitute  a  very  small  portion  of  VBARD’s  portfolio,
about 3 percent or about $70 million, while the remaining 67 percent are loans to households.

12.
The  reform  in  agriculture,  particularly  the  formation  of  private  farms,  has  created  a
demand  for  loans  by  the  12  million  rural  households  including  about  10  million  decollectivized
farms.  Concurrent  reorientation  of  the  financial  system  from  a  monobank  system  to  a  two-tier
banking structure, as well as entry of private financial institutions, has made financial services
more  accessible  to  about  6  million  rural  households.  Nonetheless,  a  significant  share  of

 4

potential demand is not served.  The Viet Nam Living Standards Survey  (1993) reports that 73
percent of all household loans were obtained from informal sources: moneylenders, friends, and
relatives.

a.

VBARD

13.
VBARD provides about three fourths of the rural credit in the country in absolute terms
and its services extend to one third of the country’s estimated 12 million rural households or 70
percent of the rural households served by the formal financial institutions (Appendix 2). VBARD
has  a  nationwide  network  of  1,282  branches,  mostly  in  districts  and  subdistricts,  managed  by
23,110 staff, of whom 313 are in the head office and 30 percent or 7,000 are specialized credit
staff.  Since  its  creation  in  1988,  VBARD  has  shown  remarkable  growth  and  transformation,
changing (i) from an institution created to serve the SOEs, to one that predominantly meets the
financial  services  needs  of  farm  households  and  the  emerging  private  sector  enterprises;  (ii)
from  being  a  conduit  for  channeling  budgetary  resources,  to  a  dynamic  financial  intermediary
and one of the largest depositary institutions in the country; and (iii) from being a direct (retail)
lending  institution  to  one  that  increasingly  adopts  indirect  means  of  credit  delivery  such  as
through  joint  liability  groups.  These  changes  have  to  some  extent  addressed  the  issues  of
access to credit at a reasonable cost, availability of deposit facilities and reduction in transaction
costs associated with retail rural lending. This reorientation has occurred against the backdrop
of  formation  of  private  farms  and  small-scale  rural  enterprises  as  part  of  the  transition  to  a
market economy. It indicates the significant role that VBARD has played in development of the
rural and agriculture sector.

The  loan  portfolio  of  VBARD  at  end-1999  was  D29,583  billion  ($2.113  million)  with  an
14.
average loan size of about $300.  This loan portfolio grew by 22 percent during 1999.  The loan
portfolio to households at D19,357 billion ($1,382 million) and to non-SOE enterprises at D1,568
billion ($112 million) accounted for 71 percent of the total loan portfolio. Loan to SOEs operating
in  agriculture  at  end-1999  was  D8,658  billion  ($618  million)  or  29  percent  of  the  portfolio.  By
loan term, 39 percent of the total loan portfolio were medium- and long-term, and the rest short-
term.  By  economic  activity,  agriculture,  forestry,  and  aquaculture  accounted  for  61  percent;
industry,  7  percent;  trading  and  services,  7  percent;  and  food  processing  and  others,  the
remaining 25 percent.

15.
International  auditors  have  audited  VBARD’s  financial  statements  since  1993.  After
recording  marginal  profits  in  1993,1994,  and  1995,  VBARD  incurred  a  marginal  loss  of  D12.7
billion in 1996. In 1997 and 1998, in compliance with stricter loan provisioning, VBARD took an
additional  charge  of  D625  billion  ($44.64  million)  to  cover  potential  loan  losses  relating  to
previous years, leading to a net loss9 of D696.6 billion ($49.8 million) in 1997 and D498.9 billion
($35.6 million) in 1998. The resulting negative net worth of D350 billion necessitated an urgent
infusion  of  D1,493  billion  into  the  legal  capital  of  VBARD  in  1998,  which  brought  the  capital
adequacy requirement (CAR) to 4.6 percent. Further infusion is necessary to build the CAR to a
minimum of 8 percent in 1998. Based on the provisional accounts of 1999, VBARD is expected
to  make  a  net  profit  of  D131  billion  ($9.4  million).  Taking  this  into  account,  and  the  projected
performance for 2000, further capital contribution of D1,563 billion is required to bring the CAR
to 8 percent in 2000.

Overdue  loans  (excluding  frozen  loans)  at  end-1998  amounted  to  D1.1  billion  or  4.5
16.
percent  of  total  loans.  Cumulative  provisions  at  end-1998  were  D1.6  billion  or  6.4  percent  of
outstanding loans. However, if frozen loans are included (1998, D1.02 billion), the overdue rates
for  1998  would  be  8.7  percent.  The  net  income  realized  on  average  loan  portfolio  was  D131
billion  or  0.5  percent  in  1999.  VBARD  managed  to  stay  profitable  due  to  its  earnings  from
noninterest income. It was able to break even on its loan operations for the year. VBARD would
need a spread of 6 percent to break even on its loan operations. The spread based on the new
scheme for interest rate determination (as approved in August 2000) would be about 6 percent.

17.
VBARD has a basic planning structure. It prepares quarterly, annual and 5-year rolling
plans  that  are  primarily  budgetary  in  nature.  It  has,  for  example,  operational  and  institutional
development  plans  for  training,  information  technology  (IT),  accounting,  and  computerization.
However, these plans are piecemeal, and VBARD has no overall corporate plan that sets out its
mission  statement,  corporate  objectives,  code  of  corporate  conduct,  strategies,  business
development and financial plans to serve as a basis for detailed operational planning. The lack
of  a  fully  integrated  planning  framework  reduces  VBARD’s  ability  to  focus  on  its  main
organizational  objectives,  restricts  the  autonomy  of  management,  and  makes  it  difficult  for
VBARD  to  justify  and  raise  the  resources  it  needs  to  enhance  its  performance.  Such  an
integrated planning system is urgently needed to provide shareholders and management with a
vision  of  the  bank’s  future  and  a  framework  for  measuring  management  and  institutional
performance. ADB’s assistance under a TA is currently helping VBARD to strengthen corporate
governance.

18.
VBARD’s management has recognized that substantive changes need to be made in the
institution to serve its clients better, to ensure its sustainability and to develop the capabilities of
its  staff  to  function  in  a  competitive  environment.  The  key  areas  to  be  addressed  are  the
development  of  new  products  and  services,  risk  management,  accounting  and  management
information  systems  (MIS),  IT  systems  development,  and  personnel  systems  and  training.
Organizational  change  in  these  areas  will  be  reflected  in  the  overall  corporate  plan  being
prepared  under  the  TA.  The  TA  will  be  completed  prior  to  project  implementation  and  will
include  detailed  recommendations  for  reform.  Given  that  the  Project  will  provide  substantial
support for implementing reforms through the institutional support component, it is appropriate
to link credit line disbursements to an agreed-upon plan of reform implementation (Appendix 3).

b.

CCF-PCF

The CCF is the apex institution of the PCF network. It was established in August 1995 and
19.
is an autonomous legal entity. PCFs are small-scale financial institutions operating in communes
and, like the CCF and Regional People's Credit Funds (RCFs), are autonomous legal entities. The
PCF network was established in March 1993 by a Decision of the Prime Minister (No. 390/TTG)
with  the  objective  of  creating  a  strong  rural  financial  system  based  on  the  concept  of  self-
managed, community-based banking, and had been operating on a pilot basis for six years up to
1999. The CCF-PCF network is a brainchild of SBV, which continues to play a critical role in its
development  and  devolution  into  an  autonomous  organization.  The  Credit  Cooperative
Department (CCD) and the Banking Supervision Department (BSD) of the SBV closely oversee
the  development  of  the  network  and  continue  to  monitor  it  under  Directive  329/CV-TTR1  on
Remote Monitoring, which is a reporting mechanism for the whole network. Because of the close
monitoring,  individual  PCFs  have  a  good  understanding  of  their  latest  financial  and  operational
situation (Appendix 4).

 6

CCF, RCFs, and the PCFs operate under the Law on Banking, Cooperatives, and Finance
20.
Companies  of  1990.  The  concepts  and  principles  governing  their  credit  and  savings  operations
are  in  line  with  ADB’s  microfinance  development  strategy.  The  Government  understands  the
importance  of  a  conducive  policy  environment  for  PCF  development,  and  to  this  end  has  made
progress  in  adopting  a  market-oriented  system  by  progressively  deregulating  interest  rate,
minimizing State intervention to address perceived market failures such as the delivery of financial
services to the rural areas, creating an enabling legal framework, developing close central bank
supervision and inspection, and adopting appropriate accounting and auditing systems.

21.
Being autonomous business entities in about 1,000 or 10 percent of the total communes in
the country, the PCFs are compelled to make their own business decisions and are accountable
for  the  results.  In  a  six-year  pilot  program  (national  evaluation  of  the  PCF  network  by  the
Government  in  December  1999)  PCFs  performed  creditably,  were  conservative  in  their  lending
operations,  and  generally  made  sound  lending  decisions.  The  results  also  show  that  the
Government has not intervened to save the PCFs that have failed to operate profitably. Indeed, 17
of 988 PCFs have been closed by the SBV for failing to meet the standards set for them, even
though  the  Government  had  placed  a  heavy  burden  on  them  by  taxing  them  at  the  rate  of  45
percent.  The  971  PCFs  that  passed  showed  an  average  profit  of  D51  million  and  recovery
performance of more than 95 percent.

From an initial 49 PCFs in 49 provinces in October 1994, the network expanded rapidly to
22.
988  PCFs,  21  RCFs  operating  in  the  poorest  53  of  61  provinces  of  the  country,  and  a  CCF  in
Hanoi by 31 December 1999. Outreach also grew significantly from 46,000 members in 1994 to
700,000  members  and  746,000  borrowers  in  December  1999.  Their  combined  total  asset  at  31
December  1999  was  D2,300  billion,  having  grown  30  times  from  D83  billion  in  1994.    The
combined  equity  capital  at  31  December  1999  was  about  D300  billion  or  $21  million,  of  which
domestically mobilized savings accounted for  D1,532 billion and the rest (D440 billion) came from
external assistance. Total disbursements since inception exceeded $1.0 billion or D14,000 billion.
By the end of 1999, the PCF network accounted for 5 percent of the market for rural credit and
was a potential competitive source of financial services to the poor and rural households.

23.
Despite  the  PCF  network's  significant  growth  and  successful  operations,  there  is  still
substantial  potential  for  improving  its  services  and  meeting  the  demand  of  the  people  for  credit
and savings, estimated at more than five times the level provided at present. Based on the recent
evaluation, supplemented by field studies, the network has developed a cautious operational plan
for  the  next  four  years.    Canadian  International  Development  Agency  (CIDA)  intends  to  provide
further  assistance  to  strengthen  the  network,  while  Deutsche  Gesellschaft  für  Technische
Zusammenarbeit  (GTZ)  has  approved  and  is  implementing    (1999-2001)  a  major  TA  for
restructuring  the  network,  specifically  structural  integration  of  the  PCF  network,  training,  and
improvement  in  operational  efficiencies.  By  December  2003,  the  network  aims  to  establish
another  360  PCFs,  increase  membership  by  723,000  or  by  100  percent,  increase  equity  of
members  by  D170  billion  (about  $12  million),  increase  mobilized  funds  by  D1,350  billion  (about
$95 million) or 90 percent, and increase other borrowings by D500 billion (about $40 million). The
network aims to double the number of loans, make larger and longer term loans, and increase the
outstanding loans by D2,580 billion or more than 2.3 times the current amount by 2003.

3.

Rural and Agrobased Enterprises

24.
The gross domestic product (GDP) share of agriculture in 1999 was about 24 percent,
but the rural and agriculture sectors accounted for three fourths of employment. Farm families
are  increasingly  turning  to  nonfarm  and  off-farm  activities  as  a  source  of  income  and

 7

employment, but they face several constraints such as availability of credit and savings facilities,
lack of market information, insufficient collateral, outmoded equipment and technology, and high
taxes.  Hitherto,  VBARD  had  concentrated  on  increasing  financial  services  to  “farm  families,”
which became the basic unit of production in the Vietnamese agricultural economy under Decree
10 in April 1988, while reducing its lending to SOEs.

25.
The  private  sector  has  grown  rapidly  from  a  negligible  base  since  the  promulgation  in
1991  of  the  Law  on  Private  Enterprises  and  the  Law  on  Companies.  In  1999  there  were  386
joint-stock  companies,  11,742  limited  liability  companies,  and  26,338  registered  household
businesses. The cooperative sector collapsed in the early 1990s, falling from nearly 43,000 in
1989  to  only  1,876  in  1995.  There  has  been  some  revival  and  in  1998  there  were  4,259
nonagricultural  cooperatives.  The  most  recent  estimate  of  the  number  of  unregistered
household businesses was 2.22 million in 1996.10 The number of SOEs fell from about 12,000 in
1990 to about 6,800 in 1999.  In terms of the capital criteria for the official definition of small and
medium-scale enterprises (SMEs), about 89.5 percent of the registered enterprises in Viet Nam
were classified as small. Some 96 percent had less than 200 employees11 (Appendix 5).

26.
Despite  this  growth,  rural  industrial  development  has  been  affected  by  policies
emanating from different ministries, which have been biased against it. In 1999, the Government
passed  the  new  Enterprise  Law  aimed  at  improving  the  legal  framework  for  businesses  and
addressing  the  contradictions  in  earlier  laws  and  decrees.  This  is  an  important  milestone  in
improving  the  environment  for  the  operation  of  micro,  small,  and  medium-size  businesses.
However,  there  are  still  several  constraints,  the  principal  among  which  are  the  inability  of
businesses  to  effectively  use  land  use  rights  and  assets  purchased  with  loan  proceeds  as
collateral, high marginal tax rates on enterprise profits that discourage business expansion, and
a prohibition on the formation of wholly private business associations. These constraints are the
subject  of  active  dialogue  between  the  Government  and  external  agencies.  The  Government
recognizes the need to resolve the policy issues concerned.

27.
The  Government  also  recognizes  that  fostering  the  development  of  micro  and  small
enterprises  will  build  the  foundation  for  significant  economic  growth  in  the  future,  while  at  the
same  time  creating  employment  opportunity,  reducing  poverty,  expanding  the  tax  base,  and
stimulating  consumption.  Credit  alone  will  not  achieve  this,  and  institutional  support  for
development  of  microbusiness  and  small-size  industries  in  the  districts  and  communes
continues  to  be  weak,  with  line  ministries  and  research  and  technical  institutes  having  little
outreach in rural areas. Rural entrepreneurs have nowhere to turn to for business assistance or
advice or to lobby with Government on issues affecting their livelihood. They could benefit from

B. 

Government Policies and Plans

28.
Concerned  over  the  widening  rural-urban  inequalities,  the  Government  has  accorded
primacy to rural development in its poverty reduction efforts, particularly in creating employment
opportunities in rural areas. Government efforts have also focused on improving infrastructure in
poor  communes  and  the  living  standards  of  ethnic  minorities,  sometimes  through  potentially
controversial  resettlement  programs.  In  preparing  for  the  2001-2005  Plan,  2010  strategy,  and
2020  vision,  the  Government  is  now  reassessing  its  Hunger  Eradication  and  Poverty Reduction
(HEPR)  and  other  social  expenditure  programs  that  provide  targeted  assistance  to  households.
ADB  has  offered  to  assist  in  this  effort,  and  in  strengthening  social  safety  nets,  such  as  health
insurance for the poor.

The Government’s goals for poverty reduction are to lift the remaining very poor above
29.
the current national poverty line by 2000 and then, over a 15-year period, to raise the remaining
poor above higher poverty lines.12 The Government aims to develop rural financial services to
reduce  rural  poverty  and  increase  employment    by  increasing  output  and  productivity  with  the
adoption  of  new  technology  and  development  of  value-added  market  surpluses  in  agricultural
and other rural businesses. In particular, the Government is pursuing a policy to (i) enhance the
outreach of lending institutions, (ii) augment resources for medium-term and long-term lending,
(iii) apply reasonable interest rate policies to mobilize resources for lending, and (iv) gradually
reduce preferential loans to SOEs.

30.
The objectives of the Government’s rural credit policies are to (i) develop the rural and
agriculture sector, (ii) increase output and productivity with the adoption of new technology, (iii)
promote  growth  of  the  commodity-economy,  (iv)  reduce  rural  poverty,  and  (v)  increase  rural
employment.

C. 

External Assistance to the Sector

31.
A  number  of  multilateral  and  bilateral  sources  at  many  different  levels  have  provided
external  assistance  for  developing  the  rural  financial  system,  to  address  the  overall  financial
system  framework,  the  supply  of  credit,  and  institutional  and  capacity  weaknesses  of  sector
institutions.  Support  for  reform  of  the  overall  financial  and  banking  sector  framework  has  been
provided  by  IMF  through  its  1994  ESAF,  by  the  World  Bank  1994  SAC,  and  by  ADB  in  1996
through the first FSPL.13 Support for the rural financial system has been provided by bilateral and
multilateral  sources  including  ADB,  World  Bank,  Agence  Francaise  de  Développement  (AFD),
International  Fund  for  Agricultural  Development  (IFAD),  and  Germany’s  Kreditanstalt  für
Wiederaufbau (KfW) (Appendix 6). ADB provided two TAs to strengthen credit appraisal capacity
and  improve  corporate  governance  at  VBARD,  while  Australian  Agency  for  International
Development  and  World  Bank  provided  support  for  financial  and  portfolio  audit  of  VBARD  by
external auditors. CIDA and GTZ have assisted in establishing and strengthening PCFs.

Assessing and strengthening the executing agency's (EA's) institutional capacity at
appraisal in subproject evaluation and project supervision help avert lapses in loan
monitoring and supervision.

Specific beneficiary targeting with clearly defined criteria is essential in microcredit
operations; otherwise, credit might be diverted to richer households on the grounds
of risk management and project viability.

Rural finance projects are successful if EAs are able to maintain their viability by
charging  commercial  interest  rates  to  cover  their  costs  and  earn  an  inflation-
corrected return.

The  use  of  subsidized  credit  and  directed  credit  distorts  the  allocation  of  credit,
complicates  monetary  policy,  and  introduces  distortions  and  inefficiencies  in  the
financial sector. The granting of liquidity credit to State-owned banks will create a
climate of lax financial discipline and breed more inefficiency.

The  classification  system  for  rural  enterprise  financing  should  be  improved  and
computerized to promptly give important information for management purposes. A
three-tier classification comprising industry class (agroprocessing, marketing, small
manufacturing,  and  services),  enterprise  and  purpose  (item

35.
The RCP shows the uneven distribution of subloans by geographic regions as well as by

region,  and  25  percent  to  the  South.  More  than  70  percent  of  the  credit  line  went  to  finance
agricultural production and livestock and poultry; the remaining 30 percent went to aquaculture
(7  percent),  agroprocessing,  services,  and  other  agricultural  activities  (23  percent).  The
distribution  varies  from  the  appraisal  report,  which  envisaged  that  half  of  the  loan  would  go  to
small-scale  agroprocessing  and  services  activities.  Also,  the  subloan  size  averaged  $500
whereas the allowable size of subloans was $5,000. This profile has several implications for the
next  Project:  there  should  not  be  subsector  allocation,  which  will  be  impractical  and
unimplementable, and there should be a policy, which allows VBARD or PCFs to charge a risk
premium for lending to those with insufficient collateral.

E.

ADB’s Country Operational Strategy

A new Country Strategy and Program (CSP) under preparation for Viet Nam is expected to
36.
be  completed  in  mid-2001,  in  coordination  with  the  Government’s  2001-2005  Plan  and  2010
Vision. The previous COS, prepared in 1995 emphasized policy and institutional reforms; social
and economic infrastructure development; environment and natural resources management; and
strengthening  of  linkages  between  urban  and  rural  areas,  and  between  Viet  Nam  and  its
neighboring  countries  in  the  Greater  Mekong  Subregion  (GMS).  Overtime,  the  sectors  assisted
under ADB operations have gradually expanded, and a stronger focus is being sought. The focus
of future ADB operations will be on poverty-reducing development, which is consistent with ADB’s
renewed emphasis on poverty reduction and with the Government’s priorities.

37.
Preliminary analysis undertaken to prepare the new CSP shows that poverty in Viet Nam is
mainly a consequence of overall low levels of income due to stunted economic growth in the past
decades. The poor are typically farmers with low levels of educational attainment. While inequality
has been growing in relative terms, income distribution is still rather egalitarian, so the scope for
redistribution  without  growth  is  limited.  In  addition,  poverty  is  largely  a  rural  phenomenon.  It  is
particularly concentrated in three areas–the northern uplands, central highlands, and north central
coast–where poverty rates are on average 50 percent higher than the national average.

38. Given  the  overall  low  level  of  income  and  the  still  fairly  equitable  distribution  of  income,
ADB’s future poverty reduction strategy for Viet Nam will address (i) economic growth and private
sector  development  pursued  through  policy  reform  and  an  improved  infrastructure  endowment;
and  (ii)  improved  human  and  social  capital,  the  latter  involving  the  strengthening  of  governance
and the legal framework for development. The new CSP is considering a geographic focus on the

 11

poorest  provinces  in  the  central  region  of  Viet  Nam.  Natural  resource  management  to  reduce
vulnerability and ensure sustainability will be systematically built into this approach.

39.
To  translate  this  approach  into  practice,  rural  development  and  rural  finance  will  be
essential. Given the already high population density, it will be necessary to increase agricultural
productivity through better seeds and techniques, irrigation, and access to markets and to inputs.
In addition, as trading in land use rights increases and farm sizes become larger, a greater share
of  the  rural  population  will  come  to  rely  on  alternative  sources  of  employment,  such  as
agroprocessing and rural-based industry. Credit and support services will be essential to support
employment generation in these sectors.

F.

Policy Issues

40.
The Government has undertaken significant reforms in the financial system, especially in
rural  finance.  With  international  assistance,  laws  were  passed  and  promulgated,  including,  in
December 1997, the Law on SBV and the Law on Credit Institutions, which have strengthened
the  financial  system.  However,  more  is  to  be  done  and  the  Government  is  committed  to
undertake  the  necessary  reforms  to  make  the  system  more  effective  in  promoting  economic
growth.  This  can  be  observed  in  the  provisions  of  the  IMF's  PRGF  and  a  second  World  Bank
SAC  under  discussion  for  late  2000  or  early  2001,  and  a  second  FSPL  of  ADB  planned  for
2001.

41.
The following policy issues and the actions envisaged in the course of the Project in the
rural  financial  and  business  sectors  were  discussed  with  relevant  Government  ministries  and
departments, VBARD, and the CCF-PCF.  Appendix 8 gives a summary policy matrix.

(iii)

Directed lending.  Some VBARD lending to SOE, of which about 15 to 20 percent
is estimated to be delinquent, is directed or policy lending made at the request of

 12

the  Government.  In  1998,  SOCBs  were  given  autonomy  and  responsibility  in
lending decisions.  To safeguard the financial strength of VBARD, the Government
will take responsibility for all such loans in VBARD’s portfolio under the provisions
of Decree 178.15 The Government will identify all SOE directed lending in VBARD’s
portfolio  and  will  issue  a  binding  statement  to  VBARD,  reconfirming  their
guaranteed  status  or  otherwise  transferring  such  debt  from  VBARD’s  balance
sheet  to  a  policy  bank  or  another  asset  management  vehicle  within  one  year  of
loan effectiveness.

Changes in portfolio composition. VBARD's new lending to SOEs in 1999 was 51
percent  of  total  lending  and  the  outstanding  was  about  30  percent  of  the  total
portfolio (having declined from 69 percent in 1995). The Government’s policy is to
progressively equitize SOEs. Present plans provide for a reduction from 6,800 to
3,000  SOEs.  In  line  with  the  changing  structure  of  the  economy,  growing  private
sector  participation  and  credit  demand,  and  prudent  asset  management,  VBARD
will continue to diversify its portfolio during the project period. VBARD will be better
able to accomplish its mandate of improving rural financial services if it reduced its
lending to SOEs and channeled these funds to households and rural businesses.
Accordingly, VBARD will reduce the share of SOE lending by 2 percentage points
per annum or a total of about 10 percent during the project period, to a maximum
outstanding SOE lending of 20 percent of total portfolio.

Improving deposit mobilization. Shortage of lending resources is a major constraint
to  expanding  VBARD  services  in  the  rural  areas  and  in  attaining  economies  of
scale  in  lending.  VBARD  recognizes  the  importance  of  being  able  to  source  its
own funds and has made it a goal to increase mobilization of private households
and small business savings by improving the services and facilities to the public.
VBARD  aims  to  double  its  savings  from  individuals,  households,  and  small
businesses  within  five  years,  that  is  to  increase  its  savings  by  15  percent  per
annum from D27,824 billion in 1999 to D53,250 billion in 2004, and to introduce
new products and services to diversify its customer base with support under the
TA to improve corporate governance.

Interest Rate Liberalization. In August 2000, the Government moved to a system
of setting a base lending rate on a monthly basis, the rate being the average rate
for the prime customers of the main commercial banks (State-owned and private)
operating  in  Viet  Nam.  Commercial  banks  are  currently  permitted  to  lend  up  to
0.3 percent per month above this rate for short-term loans and up to 0.5 percent
per  month  above  this  rate  for  medium-  and  long-term  loans.  The  Government
has confirmed its intention to remove the remaining restrictions on interest rates
in parallel with the restructuring of the banking system.

Improving  the  enabling  environment  for  nonfarm  rural  businesses.  There  is
financial  market  failure  in  the  delivery  of  financial  services  in  rural  areas  in  Viet
Nam. That can be partially corrected by providing credit lines and other financing
facilities  through  rural  financial  institutions.  However,  issues  relating  to  other
support  services  necessary

Lowering of marginal tax rates. High marginal tax rates on income and enterprise

IV.

THE PROPOSED PROJECT

A. 

Rationale

42.
The lack of fund resources, especially medium- and long-term capital, is a major constraint
to the growth of rural businesses. By providing medium- and long-term funds, the Project will help
to accelerate lending to rural businesses and encourage investment in and the adoption of new
technologies,  which  are  crucial  to  ensuring  the  survival  of  rural  businesses  in  an  increasingly
competitive  environment.  By  supporting  VBARD16  and  CCF-PCFs,  which  are  the  sole  financial
institutions servicing the rural sector, the Project will reach a major group of existing and potential
businesses.  However,  credit  alone  will  not  foster  the  development  of  rural  businesses.  Other
factors,  such  as  high  tax,  crowding  out  by  SOEs  for  scarce  credit  resources,  a  weak  legal
framework  for  private  corporations,  lack  of  information  on  markets  and  technology,  and  lack  of
collateral  should  be  simultaneously  tackled.  Many  of  these  issues  are  being  addressed  by  the
Government  under  various  programs  supported  by  external  sources.  This  Project  offers  the
opportunity to fortify some of these measures, such as, influencing a reduction in lending to SOEs
in  favor  of  private  sector  growth,  promoting  networking  and  information  dissemination  for  small
businesses  through  support  of  business  associations,  and  generally  strengthening  the  rural
financial institutions to carry out sustainable and cost-effective lending to the rural sector. It also
gives  ADB  a  chance  to  be  involved  in  ensuring  that  the  reform  recommendations  of  the  TA  for
strengthening corporate governance will be implemented over the project period and will buttress
the overall viability of the institution.

43.
The  Project  will  encourage  household  businesses  in  the  informal  sector  to  transform
themselves  into  registered  enterprises,  enabling  better  access  to  resources  and  creating  a
conducive  environment  for  business  expansion.  ADB’s  loan  will  foster  more  balanced  and
diversified portfolios in VBARD and PCFs reducing their risk exposure. Because ADB funds are
for a long term, they will strengthen VBARD and CCF-PCFs financially by reducing their duration-
and interest-variation risks and improving fund management.

44.
The RCP has shown that the demand for this type of credit is strong. Although the formal
system reaches 50 percent of rural households, about 6 million poorer households have been
bypassed.  The  loan  has  improved  the  incomes  of  poor  households  and  created  significant
employment opportunities. As major lenders to the poor, VBARD and PCFs have developed the
infrastructure  to  reach  poor  households  and  are  the  most  appropriate  and  cost  efficient
                                                
16  Currently,  VBARD’s  outstanding  loans  to  agro-industrial  enterprises  (built  over  several  years)  constitute  about  3
percent or about $70 million of its total portfolio. This is small compared with the potential demand and the capacity
of VBARD to make  loans, estimated at  about $80 million per  annum.  Although VBARD’s deposit base has  grown
rapidly in the past and will grow in the future, they consist mainly of rural household savings, which are short term
and which VBARD has used and will use for term lending up to the prudential limit allowed by law.

 14

institutions to expand financial services to those not covered so far, as well as curb the increase
in the number of poor households and the growing disparity in rural-urban incomes.

B. 

Objectives and Scope

45.
The  objective  aims  to  support  the  Government’s  efforts  to  reduce  poverty  and  promote
private sector investments in rural and agrobased businesses by providing credit. The Project will
support environmentally sound rural businesses to improve productivity, enhance product quality,
and  generate  economic  growth  and  employment.  Potential  borrowers  include  agricultural  input
producers  and  suppliers;  processors  of  fruits,  vegetables,  and  other  horticultural  crops;
processors  of  industrial  crops;  processors  of  fish  and  livestock  products;  providers  of  services
such as mechanization; small-scale manufacturers producing goods such as baskets bags, mats,
furniture,  woven  products;  and  operators  of  storage  and  marketing  businesses.    By  stimulating
savings, the Project will mobilize greater domestic resources for reinvestment in economic growth
through  financial  intermediation.  The  Project  will  be  implemented  in  rural  areas  of  Viet  Nam,
outside  the  municipal  boundaries  of  Hanoi  and  Ho  Chi  Minh  cities.  The  rural  areas  are  broadly
defined  to  include  provincial  and  district  towns  whose  economic  roles  and  functions  are  closely
linked to agricultural and rural enterprises. Special consideration will be given to areas designated
as  the  poorest  in  the  country  with  the  objective  of  narrowing  the  gap  in  incomes,  and  to  attain
sectoral and regional balance in growth.

46.
To  ensure  the  effectiveness  of  VBARD  and  CCF-PCFs,  the  Project  will  strengthen  their
operations to enable them to develop incentive systems, charge a risk premium of 1-2 percent on
subloans  with  insufficient  collateral,  improve  training  and  training  capacity,  improve  in  lending
practices and benefit monitoring and evaluation, and establish sustainable rural business support
mechanisms.

47.

The components of the Project are as follows:

1.

Rural and Agribusiness Credit Delivered Through VBARD

48.
A credit line of $45.3 million (about D630 billion) will be used as follows: (i) 40 percent to
finance  the  medium-  and  long-term  investment  and  semipermanent  working  capital  needs  of
about 3,700 rural businesses in the household and enterprise sectors, with an average subloan
size of $7,500 (about D105 million) including an average contribution of $2,650 per subloan by
VBARD;  (ii)  40  percent  to  finance  the  medium-  and  long-term  investment  and  semipermanent
working  capital  of  about  11,200  micro  businesses  with  an  average  subloan  size  of  $2,500
(including an average contribution of $880 by VBARD), and (iii) 20 percent of the credit line to
be used to finance the income-generating activities of 18,500 low-income households, with an
average subloan size of $750 (including a contribution of $265 by VBARD).

2. 

Household and Cooperative Credit Delivered through CCF-PCF

49.
A credit line of $30 million (about D420 billion) will be used, as follows: (i) 50 percent of
the  credit  line  will  finance  the  business  operations  of  about  31,000  low-income  households
below the poverty line, with an average subloan size of $750 (about D10.5 million) including an
average contribution of about $265 per subloan by PCFs; and (ii) the balance of 50 percent of
the credit line to finance 7,500 small and micro enterprises subloans of $2,500-$4,000, including
an average contribution of $880-$1,400 by the PCFs.

 15

3.

Institutional Strengthening17

50.
Under this component, mechanisms to be instituted by VBARD will provide incentives to
credit officers for good performance (to be funded from 1 percent of the spread received on the
ADB loan), a system will be established by VBARD and CCF-PCFs to recover the cost involved in
making loans to borrowers with collateral shortage (to be funded from fees from borrowers), CCF-
PCF  will  establish  a  training  and  technology  fund  (to  be  funded  from  2  percent  of  the  spread
received on the ADB loan), and $2 million will be provided under the loan for the construction of a
central  training  institute  by  VBARD  and  $1  million  to  assist  VBARD  with  implementing
comprehensive  training  curriculum  development  and  course  design  and  general  institutional
strengthening in line with the recommendations of the corporate governance TA.

$84.60  million  equivalent.  A  summary  of  the  cost  estimates  is  given  in  Table  1  and  a  more

 D. 

Financing Plan

16

E. 

Executing Agencies

VBARD  will  be  the  Executing  Agency  (EA)  for  the  rural  and  agribusiness  credit
54.
component.  The  CCF  will  be  the  EA  for  the  household  and  cooperative  credit  component.
VBARD  and  CCF  will  be  responsible  for  executing  their  respective  subcomponents  of  the
institutional strengthening component.

55.
VBARD has had experience in several projects funded by ADB, World Bank, and CIDA.
VBARD  performed  satisfactorily  in  implementing  the  RCP  and  the  World  Bank  Agricultural
Diversification  and  Bank  Modernization  and  Rural  Finance  projects.  It  is  familiar  with  ADB’s
implementation  procedures,  and  has  experienced  staff  at  its  headquarters  to  implement  a  rural
finance  project.  The  CCF  has  received  several  TAs  and  loans  from  bilateral  and  multilateral

international credit project management unit (ICPMU) of SBV, CCF has substantially implemented

 17

F. 

Implementation Arrangements

1.

Project Organization and Management

Before  loan  effectiveness,  the  respective  EAs  will  establish  a  suitably  equipped  and
56.
staffed project implementation units (PIUs) at their headquarters, each with a full-time director
responsible for their respective components under the loan. The PIUs will be the project-specific
contact and focal point for ADB for all matters relating to project implementation, management,
and  coordination.  The  PIUs  will  have  the  following  minimum  key  personnel:  a  credit  officer  to
ensure  and  facilitate  implementation  of  credit  line,  evaluation  staff  to  monitor  and  evaluate
implementation of the Project and the action plan under the corporate governance TA,  training
personnel  to  implement  training  programs  for  staff,  and  a  budget  staff  to  prepare  relevant
withdrawal applications and submit periodic reports to ADB.

57.
The  PIUs  will  be  specifically  responsible  for  (i)  submitting  withdrawal  applications  to
ADB;  (ii)  coordinating  and  consolidating  project  reporting  requirements;  (iii)  overseeing  the
implementation  of  the  various  components;  (iv)  preparing  the  bid  documents,  advertising,
evaluation, and procurement under the Project, (v) overseeing the implementation of contracts
awarded  under  (iv);  (vi)  undertaking  benefit  monitoring  and  evaluation  (BME);  (vii)  in  VBARD,
together  with  other  departments  as  appropriate,  preparing  the  incentive  scheme  and  the
procedure  for  charging  a  risk  premium  on  subloans  with  insufficient  collateral  for  approval  of
ADB,  supervision  and  reporting  on  their  implementation,  and  preparing  training  plans  and
administering the training subcomponent; (viii) in CCF, preparing the plans for establishing and
operating  the  training  and  technology  fund  for  ADB  approval,  the  basis  and  amount  of  risk
premium  to  be  charged  for  subloans  without  sufficient  collateral,  and  the  administration  of  the
training subcomponent; (ix) advertising the credit lines and supervising their implementation; (x)
conducting workshops to clarify the objectives, scope, targets, and implementation plans for the
project  components;  (xi)  carrying  out  midterm  review  and  evaluation;  and  (xii)  producing
progress reports, project completion reports, and other reports as may reasonably be required
by ADB and the project steering committee (PSC) during implementation.

2.

Project Coordination

58.
To ensure effective Project supervision and coordination, SBV will be appointed as project
coordination  agency  (PCA).    SBV  will  be  responsible  for  implementing  all  policy  aspects  of  the
Project  as  set  out  in  the  policy  matrix,  overseeing  implementation  of  the  reform  action  plans  in
VBARD and CCF-PCF, and ensuring compliance of VBARD and CCF-PCF with all covenants in
the  Loan  and  Project  Agreements.  SBV  will  also  be  responsible  for  ensuring  that  VBARD  and
CCF-PCF prepare detailed implementation plans, reviewing and approving the plans before their
submission to ADB for further approval, and ensuring that VBARD and CCF-PCF prepare timely
and comprehensive progress reports.

59.
In addition, the Government will form within three months of loan effectiveness a Project
Steering  Committee  (PSC).  The  PSC  will  be  headed  by  a  deputy  governor  of  SBV,  and  will
comprise the deputy general director of VBARD, the general director of CCF, the directors/deputy
directors  of  Foreign  Department,  Monetary  Department,  and  Credit  Cooperative  Department  of
SBV,  MOF,  and  Ministry  of  Agriculture  and  Rural  Development,  respectively.  The  Foreign
Department  in  SBV  will  be  the  secretariat.  The  PSC  will  meet  at  least  twice  yearly  to  review
progress  and  to  act  to  remove  constraints  affecting  project  implementation  including  any  non-
compliance noted by SBV in its role as PCA. The PSC will review the procedures for tendering
and awarding of contracts for the training institute in VBARD and all other procurement under the

 18

Project to ensure compliance with the appropriate ADB guidelines. The minutes of each meeting
will be submitted to ADB for information.

3.

Financing Arrangements

a.

Relending and Onlending Terms and Conditions

60.
The  Borrower  will  relend  the  proceeds  of  the  loan  in  dong  to  VBARD  and  CCF  for  the
different  project  components  under  separate  financing  agreements  acceptable  to  ADB.  The
relending  rate  will  be  variable  and  based  on  the  weighted  average  cost  of  deposit  funds  of  the
banking  system  determined  by  SBV  at  the  end  of  each  quarter  (currently  estimated  at  4.5
percent). The subsidiary loans will be for a period of 20 years including a grace period of 5 years.
VBARD  and  CCF  will  repay  principal  and  interest  in  equal  semiannual  installments  to  the
Borrower. The Borrower will bear the foreign exchange risk for the loan.

(i) 

(ii) 

VBARD  will  onlend  the  proceeds  of  the  loan  portion  designated  for  the  rural  and
agribusiness credit line in local currency to eligible subborrowers at an interest rate
that will cover cost of funds, operating costs, loan loss, and interest variation risks,
currently  estimated  at  12.6  percent  per  annum,  in  accordance  with  the  current
regulation  (Decision  No.  242/2000/QD-NHNN1  dated  August  2000).  VBARD  will
evaluate  all  proposed  enterprise  and  low-income  household  subloans  in
accordance with its standard procedures, supplemented by a cash-flow and debt-
service  analysis.  The  subloan  maturity  will  be  consistent  with  their  projected
subloan implementation period and debt-service capacity.

CCF will onlend the proceeds of the loan portion designated for the household and
cooperative  credit  line  in  local  currency  to  eligible  PCFs  at  a  variable  rate  plus  a
margin  to  cover  administrative  cost,  which  is  currently  about  1.2-1.8  percent  per
annum above the weighted average cost of deposit funds (determined by SBV at
the end of each quarter or as frequently as required by the PSC). The margin to
cover administrative costs will be decided by the management board of CCF. The
sublending rate charged by PCFs to subborrowers will be governed by the current
regulation  (Decision  No.  50/2000/QD-NHNN1  dated  February  2000)  of  the  SBV,
and  decisions  of  the  PCF  members  assembly.  The  rate  is  currently  14  percent.
PCFs will  evaluate  all proposed enterprise and low-income household subloans
in  accordance  with  prudent  banking  procedures,  supplemented  by  appropriate
cash-flow and debt-service analysis. The subloan maturity will be consistent with
the  projected  subloan  implementation  period  and  debt-service  capacity  of  the
enterprise financed.

(iii) 

Subloans will not be more than 85 percent of the cost of the subprojects. VBARD
and CCF-PCF will finance not less than 31 percent of the cost of the subproject.
Subborrowers will provide not less than 14 percent of the cost of the subproject in
the form of cash, material, or labor.

61.
The EAs may onlend to subborrowers who do not possess sufficient collateral, after due
consideration of the provisions of the regulation on collateral (Decree 165 of November 1999 and
Decree  178  dated  December  1999)  if  the  subprojects  are  financially,  economically,  and
environmentally sound. However, VBARD and CCF-PCF will charge a risk premium to cover the
risk from insufficient collateral. This scheme will be subject to guidelines to be agreed upon with
ADB.  Detailed  internal  regulations  of  VBARD  and  CCF-PCFs  for  operating  the  scheme  will  be

 19

drawn  up  and  agreed  upon  with  ADB  prior  to  implementation.  Upon  receipt  of  ADB’s  approval,
VBARD and CCF-PCF will promptly implement the scheme.

62.
In  lending  to  poor  and  low-income  households,  VBARD  and  CCF  will  apply  a  group
lending  methodology,  where  poor  households  listed  and  certified  by  the  commune  peoples
committee according to the poverty criteria published by the Government from time to time, will
be mobilized and organized into joint-liability groups. VBARD and CCF may recruit the services
of  NGOs  and  mass  organizations,  like  the  Women’s  Union,  Farmers’  Association,  etc.,  as
intermediaries and catalysts in group formation, social preparation, training, and credit supervision
of  project  beneficiaries.  The  purpose  of  social  preparation,  through  which  the  poor  will  identify
common  problems  and  aspirations  and  form  themselves  into  cohesive  groups,  is  to  assist  in
creating a social infrastructure among the poor that will serve as a basis for continuing economic
and  social  development  initiatives.  The  poor  will  then  be  encouraged  to  save  to  facilitate  their
becoming PCF members before they obtain credit. VBARD and PCFs will not discriminate against
women  borrowers  or  those  from  ethnic  minority  groups.  Instead  the  Project  recommends  that
collateral  (which  women  lack)  should  not  be  a  reason  to  deny  a  loan.  Women  and  ethnic
minorities  are  encouraged  to  borrow  under  their  names  to  undertake  livelihood  and  income-
generating activities.

63.
To successfully carry out lending to the poor, VBARD and CCF will develop appropriate
systems  and  procedures  for  microcredit  operations  and  ensure  that  its  staff  in  districts  and
communes are committed to and fully participate in the project activities by working closely and in
partnership  with  NGO  staff.  VBARD  and  CCF  will  appoint  staff  at  branch  level  to  closely
supervise, monitor, and report on subloan performance and take action as appropriate.

64.
It is widely recognized that field credit staff are overworked and under intense pressure
to  produce  results,  failing  which  they  could  be  dismissed  from  service.  To  ensure  that
performance  is  not  affected  by  the  stern  conditions  placed  on  field  credit  officers,  VBARD  will
create an incentive scheme whereby 1 percent of the subloan interest (annually) will be credited
to  an  incentive  fund  that  will  be  subject  to  guidelines  to  be  agreed  upon  with  ADB.    At  its
discretion, VBARD will apply the fund to reward existing staff through incentive payments for full
subloan  recovery  or  reduce  the  burden  on  existing  staff  by  recruiting  new  staff  using  the
proceeds of the fund. The detailed internal regulations for operating the fund the will be drawn
up and agreed upon with ADB prior to implementation.

b.

Free Limits and Subloan Appraisal Review

65.
As prescribed in its loan sanctioning authority policy, VBARD and CCF-PCFs will utilize
their internal discretionary authorities for subloan approval. It is not envisaged that ADB’s review
of  subloans  for  approval  is  necessary,  since  almost  all  subloans  will  be  within  the  authority  of
the district and provincial branches to approve. For subloans above the authority of a VBARD
provincial  branch  or  individual  PCF–$30,000  equivalent  or  above  in  the  case  of  VBARD  and
$10,000  in  the  case  of  PCF–the  subloan  appraisals  will  be  evaluated  at  the  respective  head
office and submitted to ADB for review and concurrence.

g.

Revolving Fund

To achieve the objectives of the Project and ensure that subprojects become commercially
70.
viable, credit and saving services should be made available to the beneficiaries even after project
completion. Since the credit lines to VBARD and CCF are for 20 years including a grace period of
5 years and most of the subprojects have a maturity of 3-5 years, VBARD and CCF will establish
a  revolving  fund,  within  three  months  of  loan  effectiveness,  to  which  principal  repayments  of
subloans will be credited. The revolving fund is separate from the imprest fund and will be used
for  the  sole  purpose  of  financing  subprojects  that  meet  the  objectives  of  the  credit  lines  and
contribute  to  economic  growth  and  employment  generation,  until  the  obligations  under  the
Financing Agreement have been terminated.

5.

Procurement

a. 

Goods

73.
Goods and services for the Project will be acquired in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines
for Procurement. Procurement by subborrowers will follow ADB’s Guidelines for Procurement for
small-scale  projects  under  development  finance  institution  loans.  International  shopping  (IS)
procedures  will  be  followed  for  procurement  of  equipment,  with  emphasis  placed  on  local
availability  of  after  sales  services  and  spare  parts.  For  contracts  worth  less  than  $500,000,  IS
procedures will be followed, while for contracts costing less than $100,000 direct purchase (DP)
will be followed.

b. 

Civil Works

74.
ADB  will  finance  67  percent  of  the  cost  of  civil  works  for  the  central  training  institute.
International competitive bidding (ICB) will be used for major civil works contracts in excess of
$1  million.  Specifically,  in  the  institutional  strengthening  component,  civil  works  for  the
construction  of  a  central  training  institute  in  Hanoi  will  be  grouped  in  one  package  and
undertaken by a prequalified contractor to be engaged through ICB. Prequalification criteria will
be designed to ensure that the international contractor or associates have adequate experience
and technical and financial capabilities. It is noted that some civil works contracts will be small
and  that  foreign  contractors  would  not  be  interested  in  bidding.  In  that  case,  local  competitive
bidding procedures acceptable to ADB will be followed.

6.

Training

75.
Twenty-four  person-months  of  services  of  accredited  trainers  will  be  provided  under  the
institutional  strengthening  component.  The  trainers  will  be  selected  in  accordance  with  criteria
drawn up by VBARD and CCF with the assistance of consultants recruited under this component
and  agreed  upon  with  ADB.  Trainers  requesting  accreditation  will  be  required  to  have
demonstrated  knowledge  in  their  field  of  expertise.    VBARD  and  CCF-PCF  will  ensure  that  the
detailed training programs, including selection criteria and types, duration and proposed location
of training courses to be undertaken are submitted to ADB for approval of the use of funds under
the Project.

Under  the  institutional  strengthening  component,  up  to  six  domestic  training  course
developers  and  an  international  training  specialist  serving  for  five  person-months  will  be

8.

Disbursement Arrangements

77.
 ADB’s direct payment/commitment procedure will be followed for disbursing ADB’s share
of eligible expenditure on goods procured through IS and for payments to international consultants
or training institutes. To ensure effective project implementation and timely disbursement, within
one month of loan effectiveness VBARD and CCF will open as a “servicing bank” to be appointed
by  SBV,  separate  imprest  accounts  denominated  in  US  dollars.  The  accounts  will  be  operated
and  maintained  in  accordance  with  ADB’s Handbook on Loan Disbursements  (1996).  ADB  will
advance three months of estimated expenditures into the imprest accounts: $3 million for VBARD
and  $2  million  for  CCF.  Direct  foreign  exchange  payments  or  letters  of  credit  as  well  as  local
currency expenditures may be paid out of the imprest account.

78.
The ADB statement of expenditure procedure will be used to liquidate and replenish the
imprest accounts for contracts or subloans below $50,000. Apart from the documentary evidence
of satisfactory utilization of loan advances, disbursement from the credit lines for VBARD will be
based  on  the  satisfactory  implementation  of  recommendations  under  the  corporate  governance
TA and for CCF, on fulfillment of the time-bound Institutional Development Plan proposed by the
SBV  under  the  recently  concluded  Evaluation  of  the  Pilot  Operations  of  PCF  Network.  Upon
reaching  the  amount  of  $15  million  in  the  total  CCF  credit  line  component  of  $30  million,  all
subsequent disbursements will be subject to prior approval from SBV. The Mission has reviewed
the  accounting  systems  of  the  EAs  and  finds  them  adequate  for  the  purpose  of  ADB’s  imprest
account and statement of expenditure procedures.

with  insufficient  collateral,  and  progress  of  training  subcomponents,  (ii)  reforms  that  are  being

82.

G. 

Environmental and Social Measures

83.
VBARD and PCFs will ensure that the approach to sublending is environmentally sound
and  makes  a  contribution  to  environmental  protection.  In  the  lending  processes,  VBARD  and
PCFs will raise customers' awareness of environmental responsibilities by requiring borrowers
to  provide  copies  of  all  environmental  permits  prior  to  loan  disbursement,  where  such  permits
are required; including a standard environmental loan covenant in all loan agreements to specify
the  borrowers'  environmental  responsibilities;  and  monitoring  compliance  with  loan  covenants
and  taking  corrective  action  if  noncompliance  is  detected.  24  A  summary  initial  environmental
examination is in Appendix 11.

84.
VBARD and PCFs will address poverty issues by applying a group lending methodology
where poor households, listed and certified by the commune people's committees according to
the  poverty  criteria  published  by  the  Government  from  time  to  time,  will  be  mobilized  and
organized into joint-liability groups. VBARD and CCF may recruit the services of NGOs and mass
organizations, like the Women’s Union, Farmers’ Association, etc., as intermediaries and catalysts
in  group  formation,  social  preparation,  training,  and  credit  supervision  of  project  beneficiaries.
VBARD and CCF will develop appropriate systems and procedures for microcredit operations and
ensure  that  their  staff  in  districts  and  communes  are  committed  to  and  fully  participate  in  the
project activities by working closely and in partnership with NGO staff. Further, VBARD and CCF
will  comply  with  the  portfolio  structure  criteria  that  will  ensure  that  (i)  at  least  15  percent  of
