H. 

Technical Assistance

85.
As  requested  by  the  Government,  an  advisory  TA  for  Support  of  Rural  Businesses  is
proposed to be implemented in association with the Project. The TA aims to establish on a pilot
basis sustainable rural business centers (RBCs) that will provide rural entrepreneurs and farm
households with business advice, credit facilitation service, market information, and training, as
well as to lobby with Government on issues affecting their livelihood. A TA framework and the
TA cost are in Appendix 12.

86.
Under the Project, credit lines are provided to finance the medium- and long-term capital
needs  of  rural  enterprises  and  poor  households.  However,  credit  alone  will  not  maximize  the
growth  of  these  businesses,  which  also  need  training,  information,  advice,  and  an  operating
environment  conducive  to  growth.  Line  ministries,  and  research  and  technical  institutes  have
little  outreach  in  the  rural  areas  and  are  not  able  to  provide  the  services  demanded  by  rural
entrepreneurs  and  households.  There  is  an  urgent  need  for  an  alternative  to  Government
extension  services  that  can  provide  the  assistance  required  by  rural  businesses  on  a
sustainable  basis  to  ensure  their  growth  and  success.  Private  sector  operated  services  that
cater to the special needs of rural businesses and households have been successfully tried in
other developing countries and it is proposed that they be established in collaboration with this
Project.

87.
The  TA  will  assist  the  development  of  sustainable  rural  businesses  through  the
sponsorship  of  three  RBCs.  The  RBCs  will  be  established  through  a  competitive  process
whereby individuals, private sector entities, or partnerships between public sector organizations
and  private  sector  entities  will  submit  business  plans  for  establishing  RBCs  in  selected  rural
areas. The plans will be evaluated on the basis of the services to be provided; their practicality,
effectiveness, and sustainability; their ability to leverage other funds, and likely impact on rural
entrepreneurs and households.

88.
The  TA  will  (i)  create  sustainable  support  services  for  nonfarm  rural  businesses  and
improve  the  quality  of  lending  and  monitoring  and  evaluation  of  lending  and  business
performance through the establishment of at least three pilot RBCs in different regions of Viet
Nam  using  different  modalities  for  service  delivery;  (ii)  provide  start-up  support  to  RBCs,  and
development of credit facilitation, business advisory, and training capacity in RBCs; (iii) develop
improved  lending  and  credit  management  procedures  in  PCFs  and  related  training  materials
and  courses  for  PCF  staff;  and  (iv)  develop  improved  monitoring  and  evaluation  systems  for
VBARD and PCFs to provide ongoing management information on the credit lines and on the
nonfarm rural business sector and for carrying out effective baseline and evaluation surveys.

                                                
25  See Supplementary Appendix G for social assessment.

 26

The  TA  will  provide  funding  on  a  phased  and  reducing  basis,  not  to  exceed  $100,000
89.
over three years per RBC. RBCs will be expected to be indigenous organizations or individuals.
The  cost  of  expatriate  personnel  will  not  be  eligible  for  funding.  Consulting  services  will  be
provided  to  assist  in  developing  (i)  improved  lending  and  credit  management  procedures  for
PCFs and related training materials and courses for PCF staff, and (ii) improved monitoring and
evaluating systems for VBARD and PCFs.

90.
Collectively RBCs are expected to impact directly on at least 600 rural businesses over
the  project  period.  The  total  cost  of  the  TA  is  estimated  at  $1,440,000  equivalent,  comprising
$626,000  in  foreign  exchange  cost  and  $814,000  equivalent  in  local  currency  cost.  ADB  will
finance $626,000 to cover the entire foreign exchange cost for the services of international and
domestic  consultants,  purchase  of  computer  and  training  equipment  and  software,  and
communications  and  report  production  costs;  and  $374,000  equivalent  to  cover  the  local
currency cost for start-up and administrative cost of RBCs, costs of workshops, seminars, and
training courses; and domestic travel. The TA will be financed by ADB on a grant basis from the
ADB-funded TA program. VBARD and CCF will finance the remaining local costs of $440,000
equivalent.  The  terms  of  reference  of  international  and  domestic  consultants  and  estimated
costs of various components of the TA are given in Supplementary Appendix D.

91.
SBV will be the EA. The Implementing Agency in establishing and supervising the RBC
will  be  SBV,  while  the  PIUs  in  VBARD  and  CCF  will  be  responsible  for  implementing  the
components  involving  improving  lending  and  credit  management  procedures  (in  PCFs)  and
improving monitoring and evaluation systems (for VBARD and PCFs). The PSC will approve the
use of TA funds to support the establishment of RBCs.

In accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants and other arrangements
92.
satisfactory to ADB for engaging domestic consultants, a team of consultants comprising three
internationally  recruited  specialists  will  be  selected  for  a  total  of  about  12  person-months  of
consulting  services:  an  MSE  support  service  specialist/team  leader  with  a  background  in
developing a wide range of support services and the formation of MSE support organizations, a
micro  and  small  business  training  specialist  with  a  background  in  assisting  MSEs  to  improve
management practices and in facilitating credit and access to other services, and an MSE credit
specialist with a background in MSE lending and business advisory service development. The
specialists will regularly visit Viet Nam spread over 18 months.

93.
Domestically recruited specialists in related areas will work closely with the international
specialists.  Three  domestically  recruited  specialists  with  expertise  in  media  and  information
services, credit and training, and database development will be required for a total of 18 person-
months  of  consulting  services.  The  domestically  recruited  consultants  will  have  a  key  role  in
assisting  VBARD  to  launch  the  rural  business  support  service  initiative  and  will  undertake
improvements  to  PCF  lending  and  monitoring  and  evaluation.  Their  inputs  will  be  provided  on
an intermittent basis over a period of 18 months.

V.

PROJECT JUSTIFICATION

A. 

Financial Analysis

1. 

Financial Viability and Benefits of Credit Lines

94.
The Project is expected to finance a wide range of agribusinesses and rural businesses,
including activities that can be carried out by low-income households with per capita incomes of

 27

less than $128 per year. The mix of subprojects that will be financed cannot be predicted with
any accuracy in terms of the scale and relative proportions of different activities as the Project
will be responsive to market demand. Therefore, while financial and economic analyses of the
overall  Project  are  not  feasible,  financial  analysis  of  indicative  subprojects  was  carried  out.
Credit line funds will be used for medium- and long-term investments and so benefit-cost ratios
and financial internal rate of returns (FIRRs) provide the best measures of subproject viability. A
cross section of subprojects with total investment costs of $200-$50,000 and subloan sizes of
$180-$30,000 gave benefit-cost ratios of 1.04-1.29 at a 12 percent discount rate, and FIRRs of
between  14  and  56  percent.  Sensitivity  analysis  of  reduction  in  sales  prices  and  increases  in
costs  showed  that  most  subprojects  could  withstand  5  percent  sales  reductions  or  cost
increases. Most of them remained viable with 10 percent sales reduction or cost increases. The
exceptions were subprojects involving bulk processing of commodities or characterized by high
volumes  and  low  value  added.  However,  in  general  such  businesses  are  able  to  adjust  to
commodity  price  changes  because  their  stocks  are  not  high  and  they  tend  to  be  cost-plus
businesses, adding processing costs and a profit margin to the cost of raw materials.

The  main  benefit  of  the  Project  will  be  improved  incomes  for  49,300  low-income
95.
households  under  the  VBARD  and  CCF-PCF  credit  line  components,  and  creation  of  new
employment  opportunities  in  and  generation  of  increased  incomes  for  some  7,500  businesses
under  the  CCF-PCF  credit  line  component  and  some  14,500  businesses  under  the  VBARD
credit line component. The Project’s unquantifiable benefits will be substantive. They include (i)
acceleration  of  reforms  in  VBARD  and  in  financial  sector  deepening;  (ii)  strengthening  of  staff
skills in both VBARD and CCF-PCFs through training; (iii) improvements in monitoring leading
to  more  proactive  project  management;  (iv)  the  incentives  to  VBARD  staff  to  perform  more
effectively, particularly in credit management; (v) wider access to credit through the introduction
of  the  VBARD  scheme  for  lending  to  subborrowers  with  insufficient  collateral;  (vi)  improved
environment for micro and small business operations; and (vii) introduction of support services
for micro and small businesses in rural areas.

2. 

Risks

96.
Although the Government has further liberalized interest rate and replaced the ceiling on
lending  rates  by  a  rate  determined  by  the  prime  lending  rate  of  the  nine  largest  commercial
banks (private and State-owned), it continues to control the maximum rate that can be charged
by banks. As such, there still remains the risk that interest spread may be inadequate for both
CCF-PCFs  and  VBARD,  which,  it  is  recognized,  have  to  incur  additional  costs  to  reach
borrowers and savers in the communes and villages. Any inadequacy in the spread afforded to
VBARD  and  CCF-PCFs  by  SBV  may  affect  their  ability  to  provide  acceptable  service  quality,
with potentially adverse effects on their portfolio.

Normal  commercial  credit  risks  are  associated  with  all  of  the  subloans.  Additionally,
97.
although  the  Government  is  committed  to  full  implementation  of  management  autonomy  in
financial sector institutions–and this is largely in place with private sector lending–at a local level
there  remain  risks  that  external  interference  in  lending  decisions  will  result  in  poor  loans.  The
training  of  VBARD  and  CCF-PCF  credit  staff  under  the  Project,  the  incentive  scheme  for
VBARD staff, the scheme for lending to subborrowers with insufficient collateral, the review of the
adequacy of spreads for delivering financial services, the improved monitoring systems, support
services  for  rural  businesses,  and  milestone  commitments  made  by  VBARD  for  reform
implementations will all help to mitigate these risks.

 B. 

Environment

28

98.
In general the environmental impact of subloans will not be significant. Most subprojects
will  be  small  and  any  environmental  effects  localized.  The  initial  environmental  examination
shows that there is minor potential for nuisances and hazards normally associated with small-
scale commercial enterprises, but that all of these are within the power of the subborrowers to
rectify. VBARD and PCFs will ensure that the approach to sublending is environmentally sound
and  makes  a  contribution  to  environmental  protection.  In  the  lending  processes,  VBARD  and
PCFs  will  raise  customer’s  awareness  of  environmental  responsibilities  by  using  a  simple
screening  process  to  ensure  that  activities  on  an  exclusion  list  are  not  financed;  requiring
borrowers to provide copies of all environmental permits prior to loan disbursement, where such
permits are required; including a standard environmental loan covenant in all loan agreements
to  specify  the  borrower’s  environmental  responsibilities;  and  monitoring  compliance  with  loan
covenants and taking corrective action if noncompliance is detected.

C. 

Poverty Impact

99.
Some  70  percent  of  subloans  will  go  to  about  49,500  low-income  households  with  per
capita  expenditure  of  less  than  $128  per  year,  making  the  Project  a  core  poverty  intervention
under  ADB's  current  as  well  as  year  2001  new  typology.  A  further  22,400  subloans  will  go  to
micro  and  small  businesses  with  employment  creation  potential.  In  total  some  101,700
additional  jobs  will  be  created  by  the  Project  at  an  average  annual  wage  of  $325.  At  full
development, the additional annual income of subborrowers and their employees is estimated to
be $157 million equivalent.

100.
The  additional  income  and  employment  generated  will  result  in  poor  households  being
better able to satisfy basic needs for food, clothing, and housing. Employment for the poor and
the  unemployed  will  help  to  empower  them  so  they  can  represent  themselves  better  in  their
communities.  For  the  subborrower’s  family,  increased  incomes  through  employment  of  others
may free up family labor, particularly the youth, to allow more time for education and personal
development.  Savings  from  increased  income  will  contribute  to  reinvestment  while  increased
expenditure will stimulate demand in the local economy compounding poverty reduction effects.
RBC development will empower entrepreneurs to improve the business operating environment
and in turn attract others to business.

D.

Social Dimensions

101.
By  making  credit  available  to  enable  farmers  to  invest  in  rural  business  activities,  the
Project  will  assist  in  diversifying  and  restructuring  the  sector  and  in  strengthening  the  linkages
between agriculture and nonfarm businesses. It will also widen and upgrade the rural skills base,
encourage the participation of more women in value-added activities at or near home, foster new
types  of  MSEs,  and  produce  new  types  of  goods  for  the  domestic  market  and  for  export.  It  will
contribute to alleviating regional imbalance by promoting business in rural areas that will enable
the rural economy to be integrated into the growth led by export-oriented urban industries.

102.
The  Project  will  contribute  to  the  growth  and  strengthening  of  VBARD  and  CCF-PCFs
and enhanced financial intermediation in the rural areas. It is in line with the main objectives of
the  country’s  Five-Year  Economic  Development  Plan.  The  rationale  of  increasing  production
and incomes of rural poor households and enterprises accords with both the Government’s and
ADB’s policies and strategies. Only potentially viable and profitable subprojects will be financed

 29

under  the  Project.  Based  on  the  ongoing  experience  of  the  RCP,  about  101,700  full-time  jobs
are envisaged to be created.

VIET NAM BANK FOR AGRICULTURE AND RURAL DEVELOPMENT

A.

Legal Framework, Ownership, and Basic Objectives

1.
Viet Nam Bank for Agriculture and Rural Development (VBARD) was established in March 1988
out  of  the  former  State  Bank  of  Viet  Nam's  (SBV)  Agriculture,  Fisheries  and  Salt  Production
Department.  In 1990, the Vietnamese banking system was reorganized into a two-tier structure, with
SBV relinquishing most retail lending operations and assuming the role of a central bank.  In the same
year, the various lending departments of SBV together with VBARD received their charters and were
transformed into State-owned commercial banks (SOCBs).  VBARD operates under the framework of
the Law on the SBV and the Law on Credit Institutions. It is wholly owned by the Government through
SBV and is subject to the prudential directives of SBV.  Under its charter, VBARD is allowed to carry
out  commercial  banking  and  development  banking  activities  in  all  sectors  of  the  economy  with
emphasis  on  agriculture  and  rural  development.  It  also  has  autonomy  in  operating  and  financial
management.  In  its  recently  adopted  mission  statement,  VBARD  aims  to  be  the  leading  commercial
bank  in  the  agriculture  and  rural  enterprise  sectors  and  its  overriding  corporate  objective  is  to  deliver
sustained and superior financial returns to its owners.

B.

Organization, Management, Staffing, and Operations

2.
The management of VBARD is under the overall supervision of a six-member board of directors,
which meets regularly to discuss policy matters.  The day-to-day operation of VBARD is managed by a
management  team  comprising  the  general  director  and  five  deputy  general  directors  in  charge  of  the
functional  departments.  Each  of  the  13  functional  departments  is  headed  by  a  director.  Credit
operations  are  under  the  supervision  of  two  credit  departments  namely,  Enterprise  Credit  and
Cooperative  and  Household  Credit.    At  end-August  2000,  VBARD  had  two  regional  representative
offices  in  Ho  Chi  Minh  City  and  Danang,  respectively,  4  transaction  centers,  62  provincial  branches,
689  district  branches,  1,282  intercommune  branches,  and  52  mobile  banks.  Total  staff  numbered
23,110, of which, 313 are in the Head Office and about 30 percent (7,000) are specialized credit staff.

1.

Operating Policies and Procedures

3.
The basic policies observed by VBARD are prescribed in the Law on SBV, the Law on Credit
Institutions,  the  VBARD  Charter,  and  regulations  issued  by  SBV  and  Ministry  of  Finance  (MOF)  from
time  to  time.  The  main  financial  policies  are  summarized  as  follows:  (i)  VBARD  will  give  priority  to
financing  small  and  medium-sized  enterprises  (SMEs)  in  the  agriculture  and  rural  sectors  that  are
engaged  in  food  production,  are  labor  intensive  and  are  export-oriented  or  import  substitutes;  (ii)
VBARD  will  maintain  a  minimum  adequacy  ratio  of  8  percent;  (iii)  VBARD  will  maintain  minimum
liquidity reserve ratio of 5 percent of total deposits less than 12 months and minimum current ratio of
one; (iv) the maximum ratio of short-term funds allowed for extending medium- and long-term loans is
25  percent;  (v)  assets  with  arrears  in  payment  are  to  be  suitably  classified  and  prudent  provision  for
losses made (Decision 48/1999/QD-NHNN5); (vi) single borrower limit will not exceed 15 percent of net
worth;  (vii)  VBARD  will  adopt  the  chart  of  accounts  issued  by  SBV,  including  accounting  for  loan
interest income on accrual basis (Decision 435/1998/QD-NHNN5); and (viii) VBARD’s annual financial
statements  will  be  audited  by  independent  auditors  from  FY1999.  These  policies  provide  generally
adequate guidelines for VBARD’s operations.

VBARD’s total resources grew at an average annual rate of 20.5 percent during the period, and
5.
stood at D37,503 billion ($2.68 billion equivalent) in 1999. Loan financing accounts for about 79 percent
of  total  assets  and  grew  at  about  16  percent  in  1997  and  1998,  and  22  percent  in  1999.    Deposit
mobilization grew strongly at 22 percent a year and accounted for about 67 percent of total resources.
Deposits  mobilized  traditionally  accounted  for  about  78-88  percent  of  total  lending  each  year.  Other
important sources of funds are borrowing from SBV and banks, which account for 16-27 percent during
the period.  Borrowings from international agencies accounted for 2.8 percent of total resources in 1995
and 7.7 percent in 1999. The loan portfolio at end-1999 was D29,583 billion ($2,113 million equivalent)
with an average loan size of about $300, growing by about 20 percent per annum (Table A2.2). Loans to
households and to non-SOE enterprises accounted for 71 percent of the total loan portfolio (72 percent
in  1998).  Loans  to  SOEs,  operating  mainly  in  agriculture,  at  end  1999  amounted  to  29  percent  of  the
portfolio  (having  declined  from  69  percent  of  total  loan  portfolio  in  1995).  By  loan  term,  39  percent

economic  activity,  agriculture,  forestry,  and  aquaculture  accounted  for  61  percent  (74  percent  in  1998)
followed by food processing and others accounting for 25 percent (11 percent in 1998), while industry,
and trading and services accounted for 7 percent each.

6.
The  lower  share  of  term  loans  in  the  portfolio  in  the  past  has  been  due  to,  among  others,  the
inverted lending rate structure where, until end-1997, interest rate on short-term loans was higher. This
encouraged short-term lending and was a disincentive for mobilizing long-term deposits. This has been
corrected.  Interest  rates  determination  has  been  progressively  liberalized  and  has  since  August  been
based on the average prime rate determined on a monthly basis by SBV.1 However, SBV continues to
control  the  margin  over  the  prime  rate  that  banks  can  charge  rural  borrowers.  This  puts  at  a
disadvantage the rural financial institutions whose transaction costs are relatively higher. It restrains their
potential outreach and is likely to continue to create a scarcity of medium- and long-term resources.  It is
estimated  that  VBARD  is    able  to  meet  only  a  fraction  of  the  term  resources  demanded  by  small
businesses. Because of the scarcity of credit, VBARD often resorts to credit rationing by funding a small
proportion of the project requirements or provide short-term credit (less than 12 months) where demand
is essentially of a long-term nature.

As of 31 August 2000, VBARD’s total arrears were estimated at D7,875 billion (including frozen
7.
loans of D1,024 billion) or 19.5 percent (17.4 percent excluding frozen loans) of the total loan portfolio.
Cumulative provision for doubtful debts (D2,285 billion) and frozen loans   amounted to D3,308 billion or
8.2 percent of total portfolio (42 percent of total arrears).  Frozen loans represent mostly loans to SOEs,
which are guaranteed by the Government.  Loan arrears above 360 days are about 50 percent of total
arrears, most of which (especially loan arrears of households and small enterprises) are caused by cash
flow problems contributed by VBARD’s practice of extending short-term loans for activities with a long-
term  maturity.  Other  main  causes  of  late  payments  were  business  failures  due  to  poor  economic
conditions and crop failures due to natural calamities (as opposed to willful default).

3.

Projected Operations

Details of VBARD’s projected operations for 2000-2004 are provided on para. 11 and Table 2.4.
8.
The loan portfolio is expected to increase from D29,583 billion (FY1999) to D66,800 billion (FY2004) or
average 17.7 percent a year.  Deposit mobilization is projected to grow from D 25,111 billion (FY1999) to
D52,480 billion (FY2004) or average 15.9 percent a year. Total assets are expected to increase from D
37,503  billion  (FY1999)  to  D  76,686  (FY  2004),  or  an  average  of  15.4  percent  a  year.    The  growth  of
assets  will  be  funded  mainly  from  deposit  mobilization  (70  percent);  borrowings  from  other  banks,
international  agencies,  and  SBV  (20  percent);  capital  contributions  from  government  to  meet  capital
adequacy requirement (7 percent), and accumulated earnings (3 percent).

D.

Accounting, Audit, and Financial Controls

VBARD’s  accounts  are  maintained  in  accordance  with  the  Vietnamese  accounting  standards
9.
(VAS) designed by SBV.  To facilitate central planning, the accounting systems adopted in Viet Nam for
banks  are  reasonably  uniform.    VAS  for  banks  was  recently  revised  to  bring  it  much  closer  to
internationally accepted practice.  Interest is now required to be accounted for on an accrual basis, and
as  mentioned  earlier,  assets  with  payment  in  arrears  are  required  to  be  classified  and  prescribed
provision for losses made (Decision 48).  The new chart of accounts, issued under Decision 435 by SBV
gives  guidance  on  presenting  the  balance  sheet;  however,  there  are  still  no  other  guidelines  for
preparing  and  presenting  financial  statements.    VBARD’s  skills  in  this  area,  however,  have  improved
measurably  through  experience  gained  from  international  audits  during  the  past  few  years.  The
accounting system in the head office, and provincial and district branches are computerized, while that in
the  intercommune  branches  is  partially  computerized.  The  accounting  system  consists  of  a  series  of

                                                          
1 

In August 2000, as part of its continuing effort to liberalize interest rates, SBV introduced a new system of allowing banks to
set  lending  rates,  at  a  margin  not  exceeding  0.3  percent  per  month  for  short-term  loans  and  0.5  percent  per  month  for
medium- and long-term loans above the average prime rate of 0.75 percent . The average prime rate is based on the prime
rates of nine leading local and foreign banks and will be announced by SBV on a monthly basis. In line with SBV’s reduction
of ceiling lending rates, the effective rate of interest on demand deposits decreased from 0.4-0.6 percent per month (January
1999) to 0.1-0.35 percent (December 1999); 3 month deposit rate from 0.7-0.95 percent per month to 0.3-0.45 percent; 6-
month  deposit  rate  from  0.85-1.0  percent  per  month  to  0.4-0.6  percent;  and  12-month  deposits,  from  0.9-1.1  percent  per
month to 0.5-0.65 percent.

E.

Past Financial Performance

International  auditors  audited  VBARD’s  financial  statements  from  FY1993  to  FY1998.  The
10.
unaudited accounts of 1999 indicates a net profit of D131 billion ($9.4 million).  Net losses in 1997 and
1998 caused VBARD’s net worth to become negative, necessitating an injection of capital amounting to
D  1,492.9  billion  in  1998.  This,  however,  was  inadequate.  Based  on  the  Mission’s  financial  projections
developed  with  VBARD,  further  capital  contribution  of  D1,563  billion  is  required  to  bring  the  capital
adequacy  ratio  to  8  percent  in  2000.  These  historical  results  highlight  the  importance  of  maintaining
quality  loan  portfolio,  adequate  interest  spread,  more  optimal  liquidity  management,  and  improving  the
operating ratio.  During 1996 to 1999, the interest spread was between 3.2 percent to 4.4 percent; the
ratio of cash holding and liquidity reserve with SBV to total deposits was high, ranging from 14 percent to
23 percent; the operating ratio was between 95.7 percent and 117 percent; and the return on equity was
negative  in  three  of  the  four  years.  Highlights  of  VBARD’s  financial  performance  for  1995-1999  are  in

F.

Projected Financial Performance

Highlights of VBARD’s projected financial performance for FY2000-2004 are given in Table A2.4.
11.
Details and assumptions are in Tables A2.5 and A2.6. VBARD’s financial projections were based on the
assumption that the present interest spread of about 3.8 percent will be maintained. Profitability during
the period is relatively low, with return on equity increasing gradually from 3.9 percent (FY2000) to 11.4
percent (FY2004). To maintain 8 percent capital adequacy, capital injection amounting to D1,563 billion
in FY2000 and between D300 billion to 370 billion per year from FY2001 to FY2004 has been estimated.
The  operating  ratio  is  expected  to  improve  from  97.3  percent  (FY2000)  to  91.7  percent  (FY2005).  The
percentage  of  cumulative  provision  for  loan  loss  (including  frozen  loans)  to  total  loans  is  projected  to
decline from 9.4 percent (FY1999) to 7.2 percent (FY2004).

Financial Sector Reforms and Institutional Development Efforts

13.
Though the pace of reforms in the financial sector could have been faster, progress was noted on
all policy reform areas covered by the ADB-financed Financial Sector Program Loan (FSPL).2  The World
Bank  also  indicated  progress  on  the  reform  agenda  under  its  projects.    Among  the  recent  measures
initiated under the FSPL, the introduction of asset classification and provisioning norms3 and new chart
of  accounts4  will  address  the  issues  of  portfolio  quality,  provisioning  requirements,  and  transparency.
SBV has also issued specific guidelines5 to ensure autonomy in lending decisions.

On the institutional development side (i) VBARD’s equity has been raised to $157 million in 1998,
14.
(ii)  accounts  are  being  audited  by  an  international  auditing  firm6  and  recommendations  introduced
gradually,  (iii)  new  credit  regulations7  emphasizing  in-depth  credit  appraisal  have  been  issued,  and  (iv)
changes have been made in organization structure to create more specialization in product development.
Credit  appraisal  skills  are  being  enhanced  under  the  ADB-financed  Rural  Credit  Project  and  will  be
continued  under  the  Rural  Enterprise  Finance  Project,  as  well  as  the  technical  assistance  for

Strengthening Corporate Governance at VBARD. Support for institutional development is also provided

15.
The  institutional  development  agenda  for  VBARD  consists  of  (i)  corporate  governance;  (ii)
instituting  a  management  information  system  (MIS)  to  serve  the  requirements  for  loan  management,
credit  appraisal,  portfolio  analysis,  risk  management,  and  measurement  of  financial  performance
(product  wise);  (iii)  product  development  (both  deposits  and  credit)  and  emphasis  on  savings
mobilization;9  (iv)  expediting  the  alignment  of  the  current  accounting  system  to  international  standards
and integrating it with MIS; and (v) step up investment in training, particularly for enhancing technical and
financial appraisal and accounting.  Improvements on the above aspects require substantial investments
and  VBARD  may  not  be  able  to  implement  all  of  them  immediately  or  even  in  the  short  term  without
external support.

VBARD’s capacity to implement the credit component under the project is considered adequate.
16.
VBARD  is  the  predominant  and  in  many  provinces,  the  only  formal  source  of  term  financing  for
agriculture. VBARD’s branch network and resource base enable it to cater to the heterogeneous demand
for  financial  services  in  the  rural  areas  and  give  it  a  sufficient  degree  of  decentralization  of  lending
operations to facilitate credit delivery. It has traditional functional links with the extension agencies up to
the  commune  level.  VBARD  has  exhibited  a  progressive  approach  by  actively  pursuing  an  institutional
development agenda to enhance its financial soundness and competitiveness.  Its organization chart is
in Figure A2.

VBARD SUMMARY ACTION PLAN1

Action

A. Banking Services Development Plan
Payment  Product  Development:  make  specified  improvements  to  payments  products  and
introduce  new  products,  such  as,  bulk  processing  of  direct  credits,  introduce  direct  debits,
extend payment order facilities to branches, introduce standing order facilities, and expand utility
payment service to cover bill payment.
Deposit  Product  Development:  make  specified  improvements  to  deposit  products  and
introduce  new  products,  such  as,  overdrafts,  annual  limit  reviews,  variable  interest  rates,
transaction  charges  on  checks  and  debit  cards;  introduce  lottery  products,  pension  savings
account; rationalize processing of savings products; introduce variable rates on term deposits.
Loan  Product  Development:  improve  existing  loan  products  and  introduce  new  products  to
widen  the  range  of  services,  such  as,  overdrafts,  annual  limit  reviews,  variable  interest  rates,
transaction  charges  on  checks  and  debit  cards;  introduce  lottery  products,  pension  savings
account;  rationalize  processing  of  term  lending  products;  introduce  variable  rates  on  products;
introduce housing loan, education loan, and leasing loan products.
Delivery  and  Service  Product  Development:  extend  the  range  of  delivery  and  service
products offered to customers, such as, group account facility, expanded ATM facility integrated
with  customer  accounts,  issue  ATM/debit  cards,  pilot  test  internet  banking  services,  provide
insurance  products,  offer  share  dealing  services,  develop  farm  accounting  advice  service.  Roll
out to branches which meet IT requirements by 31-12-04.
B. Risk Management Plan
Risk  Management:  Adopt  new  risk  management  policies  to  improve  risk  management.  Make
specified  improvements  to  the  ways  in  which  credit  risk  is  managed,  moving  toward  the
principles set out by BIS.
Liquidity  Risk  Management:  make  specified  improvements  to  the  ways  it  manages  liquidity
risks, moving toward the principles set out by BIS.
Interest Rate Risk Management: make specified improvements to the ways it manages interest
rate risk, moving progressively toward the principles set out by BIS.
Foreign  Exchange  Risk  Management:  make  specified  changes  to  the  ways  in  which  it
manages foreign exchange risks.
Operational  Risk  Management:  make  specified  changes  to  the  ways  in  which  it  manages
operational risks, moving toward the principles set out by BIS.
C.  Accounting and MIS Plan
Budgeting: make specified improvements to the budgetary process, such as, update business
planning guidelines first issued in August 1993, create and operationalize a budgeting manual,
develop  uniform  budgeting  model  software  for  use  across  bank,  speed  up  budgetary  process,
monitor on a quarterly basis.
Loan provisioning: develop historical records of the incidence of bad debts within loan portfolio,
stratified by ownership, category and industry sector. Develop a grading methodology to support
an IAS provision based on the historical review. (The records will be held outside the nominal
ledger in the banks loan database). Over time modify the percentages used to calculate
provision levels appropriate to its own circumstances; modify the branch loan system to
incorporate 4 additional fields, for industry sector, ownership category, risk rating/grade. IT Dept.
will develop software.
Interest Receivable: establish a policy on accruals of interest receivable. Modify the IT system
to sum up total interest receivable accruals for each  grade of loan to assist in determination of
interest receivable recognition to the income statement.
Borrowings: apply accrual accounting consistently throughout the bank. Take steps to enforce
compliance at all branches.
Capital and Reserves: centralize payments from the welfare and bonus and other reserves at
head office. Carry out an analysis of movements in reserves and reconcile these to accounting
records. Report separately on use of funds.
Agency  Arrangements:  as  current  regulations  do  not  provide  for  an  off-balance-sheet
treatment of these loans, VBARD will flag all agency arrangements through IT modifications in its
loan system, in respect of both the funding source and the loan portfolio.
Intrabank  Transactions:  reconcile  and  clear  off  income  and  expense  on  a  regular  basis.
Customer related intrabank balances to be reconciled within one month of year-end. An online

Cash, Gemstones and Interbank: make adjustments to reflect transactions initiated by counter

Treasury  Bills  and  Securities:  distinguish  between  securities  held  for  investment  and  trading

regulations require that zero coupon securities be recorded at face value, VBARD will maintain a
separate  deferred  income  account  which  is  used  to  record  the  total  discount  at  the  time  of
purchase and from which the discount is amortized over the holding period).
Investments:  account  for  associates  and  joint-ventures  under  the  equity  method.  Consolidate
subsidiaries and create procedures to assess and record a provision for diminution in value for
other long term investments if required.
Fixed Assets: where the estimated useful life of fixed assets are significantly different from the
range provided by the MOF, VBARD will apply to the MOF for permission to use more accurate
movements in depreciation of fixed assets. A listing of fixed assets purchased through reserves
will be created and maintained separately.
Deposits, Savings, and Certificates of Deposit: consistent accrual accounting policies will be
applied throughout the bank. Internal audit will enforce compliance; accounts of employees (both
deposit  and  loans)  within  reserves  will  be  listed  and  consolidated  at  head  office;  and  the  un-
amortized discount for certificates of deposit will be recorded in a separate account,
Guarantees,  Commitments,  and  Contingencies:  make  guarantees  and  other  commitments
subject  to  the  same  regular  monitoring  that  applies  to  other  extensions  of  credit.  Risk  will  be
assessed  and  graded  and  appropriate  provisions  made  in  the  period  in  which  loss  becomes
likely. Income will be matched to the life of the off-balance-sheet exposure. IT systems changes
will  be  made  to  report  undrawn  irrevocable  credit  commitments,  broken  down  into  less  than  1
year and more than 1 year.

ALCO  Reporting:  ALCO  will  receive  the  following  reports  in  the  following  areas  in  addition  to
those  reports  already  prepared  by  the  bank  for  risk  management.  Liquidity  will  be  monitored
through the development of maturity analyses, cash flow statements, analyses of the portfolio of
liquid assets, summaries of undrawn lending commitments and a forecast of funds and the use
of funds; foreign currency exposures through regular position account reports (VBARD already
prepares  foreign  currency  trial  balances  at  a  branch  level.  As  a  stop-gap  measure,  simple
programming  changes  will  be  made  in  the  existing  systems  to  enable  this  information  to  be
consolidated  on  a  bankwide  basis)  –  interest  rate  risk,  through  interest  rate  gap  analysis;  and
concentration  risk,  through  consolidated  reports  on  the  concentrations  of  assets  and  liabilities
with customers, counterparties and sector.
Treasury Reporting: Treasury will receive reports on liquidity ratios; analysis of treasury assets
and  liabilities;  average  cost  of  wholesale  funds;  forecast  on  currency  position  account  and
current  currency  position  reports,  both  on  and  off  balance  sheet;  maturities  analysis;  depositor
volatility projections; interest rate mismatch reports; sensitivity analyses for liquidity and interest
rates;  treasury  profit  and  loss;  exception  reports  showing  breaches  of  limits,  unauthorized
transactions, cancelled or failed deals, etc; unrealized profit and loss; unmatched deals; overdue
settlement.
Settlement Reporting: Settlements  will receive the following additional information: summaries
of  interbank  and  interbranch  settlement;  transaction  volumes;  fees  and  commissions  earned;
cashflow forecast; reconciliation report to counterparty statements, confirmations, etc; exception
reports  (transaction  processing  errors,  limit  excesses,  unauthorized  transactions  etc;  unused
limits.
Banking  Services  will  receive  reports  with  the  following  additional  information  -  number  and
volume  of  deposits  CDs,  blank  CDs;  number  of  accounts  opened  and  closed;  CDs  issued;
dormant  and  suspense  accounts;  transaction  volumes,  value,  number,  number  of  customers;
customer base analyses including concentrations; customer complaints; maturity analyses; and
depositor volatility forecasts.
Administration and Human Resources will receive reports covering the following information -
ratios of overheads to total assets and net income; average assets and accounts to employee;
analyses of overheads by type; number of employees by position, branch, business unit; labor
turnover, demand and supply forecasts.
Planning and Budgeting will receive reports detailing performance to date, by branch, business
unit against budget.

D.  Human Resources Plan

Job  Description  Development:  develop  specific  job  titles  for  each  professional  staff  position
including those of the Director General and the Directors. Define and document the job content,
the  performance  standards  for  each  activity  and  the  levels  of  competence  (skills  profile)  and
minimum  academic  entry  level  for  each  job.  Determine  the  basic  remuneration  of  each  job.
Specify  the  reporting  lines,  and  accountabilities.  Verify  the  accuracy  and  coverage  of  job
descriptions  with  job  holders  and  their  supervisors;  finalize  job  descriptions  and  prepare  a
detailed  plan  for  implementation  simultaneously  bankwide;  and  implement  the  new  job
descriptions.
Strengthening  of  Recruiting  Results:  form  alliances  with  at  least  two  higher  education
institutions  that  currently  provide  education  in  banking,  business,  economics,  finance  and
agriculture. Provide the institutions with an understanding of the job competencies it needs from
new  employees;  and  discuss  how  to  close  the  gap  between  graduate  competencies  and  job
requirements. Assist the institutions to incorporate into their curricula elements that will help to
close  the  gap;  actively  promote  opportunities  with  VBARD  for  graduates  of  these  institutions;
and prepare a detailed plan for implementation and implement the new procedures.
Revisions to Staff Hiring Procedures: actively promote itself as an employer. Advertise each
specific job vacancy internally and externally. Assess internal and external applicants in relation
to the specific requirements of the job description (including where appropriate non Vietnamese
nationals) and offer each position to the applicants that best satisfy the requirements of the job
description  in  order  of  merit.  Carry  out  a  specific  training  needs  analysis  for  each  new  staff
member  and  prepare  a  timebound  training  plan  to  ensure  that  any  shortfalls  in  levels  of
competence (job skill) requirements are addressed within three months of recruitment. Prepare a
detailed plan for implementation of the new procedures.
Revisions to Performance Evaluation Procedures: reduce the frequency of evaluation to six
months. Modify the evaluation procedure to incorporate grading of performance by the job holder
and  the  job  holder’s  immediate  superior.  Comment  on  any  differences  in  assessment.
Restructure the evaluation in relation to the job description so that performance is assessed in
relation  to  the  required  skill  levels  in  business  awareness,  business  development,  written  and
verbal  communication,  customer  service,  decision  making,  initiative,  numeracy,  planning  and
organization,  teamwork  and  team  leadership,  use  of  systems  and  work  standards.  Include
behavioral aspects in the evaluation.
Revisions to the Compensation System:   remove monthly adjustments to the compensation
stemming from the performance appraisal (which will now be at six monthly intervals) and pay
each  employee  a  fixed  monthly  basic  salary  in  conformance  with  the  salary  scales  and grade
intervals  applicable  to  each  job.  Allocate  bonus  payments  in  relation  to  annual  performance
within  the  allowable  amount  for  total  compensation  and  in  accordance  with  the  revised  bonus
policy; and implement the changes in remuneration.
Implementation  of  Revised  Promotion  Procedures:  advertise  each  and  every  promotion
opportunity  bankwide.  Consider  only  applicants  that  have  performed  above  satisfactory  and
have no unsatisfactory ratings in the preceding year. Assess applicants in relation to the specific
requirements  of  the  job  description  (including  where  appropriate  non  Vietnamese  nationals).

PEOPLE’S CREDIT FUND SYSTEM

A.

Legal Framework, Ownership, and Basic Objectives

1.
The  People’s  Credit  Fund  (PCF)  network  was  established  in  March  1993  (Decision  No.
390/Ttg  of  the  Prime  Minister)  under  the  auspices  of  the  State  Bank  of  Viet  Nam  (SBV)  with  the
objective  of  creating  a  strong  rural  credit  system  based  on  the  concept  of  self-managed
community-based banking. The PCFs are based on the Desjardine Credit Union model of Canada.
A  strong  motivation  behind  the  launch  of  the  PCF  system  was  to  restore  savers  and  investors
confidence  that  was  lost  when  about  7,000  locally  licensed  cooperatives  went  bankrupt  in  1990-
1991. The PCF concept was shaped by and is still affected by lessons from that experience. The
system  comprises  three  tiers:  PCFs,  regional  people’s  credit  fund  (RCFs),  and  central  people’s
credit  fund  (CCF),  each  an  autonomous  legal  entity.  PCFs  are  small-scale  financial  institutions
operating  in  the  communes.  RCFs  operate  in  the  provinces,  providing  liquidity  and  technical
support to member PCFs. CCF is the apex entity established in August 1995, operating in Hanoi
and  Ho  Chi  Min  City  and  entrusted  with  the  responsibility  of  providing  overall  funding,  business,
and  technical  support  to  the  entire  network.  The  PCFs,  RCFs,  and  CCF  are  governed  by  the
framework of the Law on Cooperatives, the Law on the SBV, the Law on Credit Institutions, Decree
No. 42/CP on PCF, and the Charter of CCF. They are subject to SBV’s prudential guidelines and
their  annual  accounts  are  audited  by  SBV.  The  PCF  is  a  form  of  cooperative  credit  institution
organized  voluntarily  by  members  of  a  community  to  mobilize  savings  and  to  provide  credit  and
financial services for the primary objective of improving the economic and social well–being of its
members.  It is operated on the principles of cooperative self-help for mutual benefit, equal rights in
management,  and  share  in  profit;  it  is  autonomous  and  self-governing.  Under  its  charter,  CCF  is
allowed  autonomy  to  carry  out  commercial  banking  and  development  banking  activities  with  the
primary objective of assisting and supporting the PCF system.

2.
During  the  six  year  (1993-1999)  pilot  phase,  SBV  played  a  pivotal  role  in  organizing  and
ensuring the PCF system’s success in selecting communes with good business potential, licensing
of  PCFs,  secondment  of  SBV  staff  to  assist  with  PCF  development,  providing  office  space  and
capital  funds,  and  providing  comprehensive  training  to  PCF  staff.  CCF  and  RCFs  are  majority-
owned by SBV.  As of 30 June 2000, the network comprises one CCF, 21 RCFs and 960 PCFs,
operating in 53 (out of 61) provinces and  reaching about 10 percent of communes in the country. It
is estimated that the PCF network presently provides about 4 percent of the outstanding credit in
the formal rural financial sector. In provinces where there are no RCFs, SBV branches (currently
29) assume the role of RCF.  Equity capital consists of 2 classes of shares: qualifying share (for
membership) and permanent share (for dividend). Qualifying share for PCF costs D50,000 ($3.50),
which has enabled even low income households to become members: and that for RCF and CCF
costs  D10  million  ($710).    The  minimum  paid-in  capital  of  PCF  is  D100  million  and  that  of  RCF,
D1.0 billion. The paid-in capital of CCF as of 30 June 2000 amounted to D110.9 billion, of which,
D10.9  billion  is  subscribed  by  PCFs  and  RCFs,  D  20  billion  by  the  four  State-owned  commercial
banks  (SOCBs)  at  D5  billion  each,  and  the  balance  D80  billion  by  SBV.  The  combined  paid-in
capital  of  RCFs  and  PCFs  as  of  30  June  2000  amounted  to  D22.2  billion  and  D165.7  billion,
respectively.  As  of  30  June  2000,  PCFs  have  765,490  members,  CCF  has  841  members,  and
RCFs have 4,068 members.

B.

Organization, Management, Staffing, and Training

The  management  of  CCF  is  under  the  overall  supervision  of  a  5-member  management
3.
committee  and  a  3-member  supervisory  committee  appointed  by  a  24-member  board  of
management  who  meet  twice  a  year  to  discuss  policy  matters.  The  annual  members’  assembly
appoints  the  board  of  management  for  a  4-year  term.  The  president  of  the  board  of  directors,

 47

Appendix 4, page 2

general  director,  and  supervisor-in-chief  are  representatives  from  SBV.  A  management  team
comprising  the  general  director  and  two  deputy  general  directors  in  charge  of  nine  functional
departments of SBV carries out day–to-day management. Figure A4 gives the organization chart of
CCF.  As  of  31  August  2000,  CCF  had  120  staff,  102  at  its  head  office  in  Hanoi  and  18  at  its
branch.  Eighty-five percent of the staff are university/college graduates and 90 percent are below
40  years  of  age.    CCF  has  the  following  main  functions:  (i)  handling  and  mediating  fund  in  the
whole  network;  (ii)  ensuring  liquidity  for  the  whole  system;  and  (iii)  liaising  with  the  Government,
SBV, credit institutions, and government and nongovernment organizations to ensure availability of
lending  resources.  CCF  provides  loans  to  and  receives  deposits  from  PCFs  through  RCFs.  In
places where RCFs are not available, CCF lends and accept deposits via SBV branches. Interest
rates are applied consistently all over the country.

4.
Being  a  relatively  new  institution,  CCF  has  not  handled  many  international  credit  projects
and  therefore  lacks  experience.  The  linkage  with  PCFs  needs  strengthening  and  changes  in
supervisors and managers involved in the execution of international credit projects should be kept
to a minimum.  At CCF, a project implementation unit (PIU) has been established and staffed with
a  team  of  full-time  officers  and  provided  with  adequate  resources  to  implement  the  Rural  Credit
Project. PIU staff have been trained in project management, accounting, and procurement by SBV.
They  are  considered  as  a  strong  asset  of  CCF  to  handle  the  Rural  Enterprise  Finance  Project
(REFP) and similar projects in the future.

5.
PCFs and RCFs now have about 7,000 staff. Their staffing structure is similar: members of
the  board,  a  director,  a  deputy  director,  a  supervisor,  one  or  two  credit  officers,  one  accountant,
and  one  cashier.    Most  management  staff  are  college  graduates  and  have  experience  in

 48

Appendix 4, page 3

management,  banking,  and  business.  SBV  requires  all  PCF  staff  to  undergo  compulsory  training
before the establishment of PCF. Training is conducted at SBV’s Banking Institute or at provincial
SBV  branches  and  lasts  from  one  to  three  months.  Training  courses  cover  banking  and  finance,
law  on  banking,  regulations  and  management  of  PCF,  accounting  and  financial  management,
credit  appraisal  of  projects,  and  internal  controls.  During  the  pilot  period,  training  was  fully
subsidized by SBV. Under the training program arranged by the Department of Credit Institutions
of SBV for January 2000-June 2001, about 6,700 PCF staff will undergo training at an estimated
total  cost  of  D13  billion  ($928,000)  financed  by  dividends  of  SBV  from  the  PCF  system.  Training
cost in the past was partly funded by dividends and by a special budget from the Government.

C.

Operations

1.

Operating Policies and Procedures

6.
The basic policies to be observed by PCFs, RCFs, and CCF are prescribed in the Law on
Cooperatives,  the  Law  on  SBV,  the  Law  on  Credit  Institutions,  Decree  42/CP  on  PCF,  the  CCF
charter, and by SBV and the MOF.  The main financial policies are summarized as follows:   (i) give
priority  to  financing  households  and  enterprises  in  the  agriculture  and  rural  sectors  that  are
engaged  in  food  production  and  are  labor-intensive;  (ii)  maintain  minimum  adequacy  ratio  of  8
percent;  (iii)  maintain  minimum  liquidity  reserve  ratio  as  prescribed  by  SBV  and  maintain  a
minimum  current  ratio  of  one;  (iv)  maintain  a  maximum  ratio  of  25  percent  for  short-term  funds
extended for medium- and long-term lending; (v) classify loan arrears and make prudent provision
for losses (Decision No.48); (vi) single-borrower limit shall not exceed 15 percent of net worth; (vii)
adopt  the  chart  of  accounts  issued  by  SBV,  including  accounting  for  loan  interest  income  on
accrual  basis;  (viii)  annual  financial  statements  will  be  audited  by  independent  auditors  from
FY1999;  and  (ix)  comply  with  SBV’s  regulation  on  remote  monitoring  of  cooperative  credit
institutions  (No.  329/CV-TTR1).  These  policies  provide  generally  adequate  guidelines  for  the
operations of the PCF system.

2.

Accounting, Audit, and Financial Controls

7.
The accounts of CCF, RCFs, and PCFs are maintained in accordance with the Vietnamese
accounting standards (VAS) designed by SBV. Their annual accounts have been audited by SBV
within  three  months  after  the  year’s  closing.  The  accounting  systems  adopted  by  banks  in  Viet
Nam  are  reasonably  uniform.    VAS  for  banks  was  recently  revised  to  bring  it  much  closer  to
internationally accepted practice.  Interest is now required to be accounted for on an accrual basis,
and assets with payment in arrears are required to be classified and prescribed provision for losses
made (Decision 48/1999/QD-NHNN5). The new chart of accounts, issued under Decision 435 by
the SBV, gives guidance on presenting balance sheets; however, there are still no other guidelines
for preparing and presenting other financial statements.  The skill of CCF, RCFs, and PCFs in this
area is limited. The accounting system in CCF and RCFs is computerized. In PCFs, it is essentially
manually operated, with only a few PCFs using computers.  PCFs are subject to close supervision
by SBV. An SBV branch conducts regular on-site inspection, and SBV head office inspectors carry
out periodic inspection. Under Directive 329 on remote monitoring, PCFs are required to submit a
monthly report on loans, deposits, and loan arrears to SBV and RCF. To ensure quality loans, CCF
adopts strict criteria in screening loan application by PCFs: (i) the PCF should be profitable in two
consecutive years; (ii) overdue debt should not exceed 5 percent of total loans; (iii) total lending to
the PCF will not exceed 70 percent of the PCF’s outstanding loans; and (iv) mobilized deposit of
the PCF should constitute at least 30 percent of its total resources.

 49

3.

Past Operations and Financial Performance

8.
SBV  made  a  comprehensive  evaluation  of  the  operations  and  performance  of  the  PCF
system in the pilot phase (1993-1999) at the end of 1999.  The study confirmed the overall success
and  suitability  of  the  PCF  system  to  deliver  financial  services  to  rural  communities.  PCFs
performed  an  active  financial  intermediation  function  at  the  rural  grassroots  level  and  have  given
rural  borrowers  and  savers  access  to  financial  services,  made  available  loan  funds  to  rural
borrowers at reasonable cost, successfully enforced and emphasized savings and credit discipline,
employed simple and practical procedures, and provided members a choice of savings and credit
products.

Total resources of the PCF network grew at an average annual rate of 49.8 percent from
10.
D453.7 billion in 1995 to D2,286.1 billion (equivalent to $163.3 million) in 1999. Loan outstanding,
which accounted for about 88 percent of total assets in 1999, registered strong growth of about 50
percent a year from D396 billion (1995) to D2,004 billion (1999). Deposit mobilization grew strongly
at  57  percent  a  year  from  D262  billion  (1995)  to  D1,606  billion  (1999),  and  as  a  source  of  funds
accounted for about 58 to 71 percent of total resources and 66-80 percent of total loans during the
period. This high growth rate is attributable to the proximity to rural households of the commune-
level network of the PCF system and the higher interest offered by PCFs on deposits. This is made
possible by the higher lending rate PCFs can charge their borrowers (up to 18 percent per annum)
compared  with  other  banks.    It  is  also  evident  that  the  rural  people  have  confidence  in  the  PCF
system,  which  is  bolstered  by  the  assurance  that  their  deposits  are  insured.  Other  important
sources of funds are shareholders’ capital contribution and retained earnings, which accounted for

 50

Appendix 4, page 5

21  percent  of  total  resources;  and  borrowings  from  SBV  and  international  agencies  which
accounted for about 7 percent of total resources in 1999.

11.
Since  its  establishment  in  1993,  the  PCF  network  has  been  profitable,  achieving  a  net
income of D16.1 billion (1995) to D65.6 billion (1999) or return on assets of between 3.2 percent
and 6.0 percent.  In the past three years, return on equity was between 12.9 and 15.3 percent and
the operating ratio averaged about 80.4 percent, which is satisfactory. The capital adequacy ratio
was maintained at a satisfactory level of 22-43 percent during the period.  PCFs have been able to
maintain  financial  sustainability  at  a  reasonable  interest  spread  of  6-9  percent  in  the  past  four
years  mainly  because  SBV  has  allowed  the  ceiling  lending  rate  for  PCFs  to  be  as  high  as  1.5
percent a month (despite numerous successive reductions in interest rate in the financial sector).
PCFs are also allowed a preferential tax rate of 16 percent compared with a corporate tax rate of
32 percent.  At the end of 1999, about 384,000 households benefited from loans granted by PCFs
totaling    D2,004  billion.  Average  loan  size  was  D5.2  million  ($370).    Most  of  the  loans  are  short-
term (12 months and less), generally in line with the production cycle of agriculture. Loan purposes
are diversified with 60 percent of the loans outstanding going to agriculture production, 28 percent
to  services,  12  percent  to  agroprocessing  and  traditional  crafts  and  3  percent  to  consumption.
Average loan sizes differ among the provinces with a wide range between D500,000 ($35) to D50
million ($3,500). This reveals the great variety in socioeconomic status of PCF members. The PCF
network has a strong interest in lending to women and low-income households and has to develop
new  products  and  methods  to  realize  this  interest.  To  date,  female  members  account  for  32
percent  of  the  total  membership,  and  poor  members  account  for  about  20  percent  of  total
customers. Because PCFs operate in communes, they understand clients well. The credit quality of
PCFs is basically good with loan repayment rates higher than 96 percent. Most of the loans from
PCFs are secured by collaterals like land or land use certificates.

4.

Management Information System (MIS) and Information Technology (IT)

Under Directive 329/CV-TTR1 on Remote Monitoring, a reporting mechanism for the whole
12.
PCF network is now in place.  Staff at each PCF has a relatively good grasp of their PCF’s financial
position. On a monthly basis, PCFs send, among others, reports on loans and deposit outstanding
and loan arrears to the Banking Supervision Department of SBV provincial branches.  The reports
are  collated  and  sent  to  BSD  of  SBV  head  office.  The  SBV’s  Credit  Cooperative  Department
(CCD),  in  coordination  with  the  BSD,  prepares  and  sends  the  necessary  operating  report  to  the
governor and concerned agencies. For effective management of the whole network, it is necessary
to develop an efficient MIS.  However, due to budgetary constraints, only about 11 percent of PCFs
use computers and development of an efficient MIS is constrained.

5.

Role of SBV

The  PCF  system  is  a  brainchild  of  SBV.  SBV  played  a  critical  role  in  establishing  and
13.
developing the network. Two important departments overseeing its orderly development are CCD
and  the  BSD.  The  CCD’s  major  functions  (with  regard  to  PCFs)  are  summarized  as  follows:  (i)
promulgate and amend the legal framework governing the orderly and efficient development of the
PCF system, (ii) issue licenses to PCFs, (iii) coordinate staff training of PCFs, (iv) develop the MIS
of the PCF network, (v) coordinate with BSD on monitoring and supervising the PCFs, and (vi) be
the implementing agency for technical assistance (TA) projects from external agencies.

BSD’s  major  functions  are  to  (i)  regularly  supervise  PCF’s  compliance  with  prudential
14.
standards  and  the  laws  and  regulations  governing  PCFs,  (ii)  implement  the  remote  monitoring
system  promulgated  under  Directive  No.  329,  (iii)  investigate  any  dispute  in  PCFs  and  make
recommendations on its resolution to the governor, (iv) mete out sanctions on violation of law and

 51

Appendix 4, page 6

regulation,  and  (v)  formulate  and  amend  prudential  standards  with  the  objective  of  promoting
efficient compliance.

15.
It  is  the  express  wish  of  SBV  for  CCF  to  progressively  take  over  the  direct  management
functions like inspection and internal audit, and the MIS for the whole PCF network, and CCD and
BSD  will  carry  out  only  their  central  banking  role  of  supervision.    SBV  realizes  that  for  this  to
happen,  CCF  will  need  to  be  adequately  staffed  with  trained  personnel.  As  such,  responsibilities
will be handed over to CCF in a phased manner.

6.

Projected Operations and Financial Performance

16.
The  comprehensive  evaluation  of  the  PCF  system  confirmed  its  overall  success,  but  also
highlighted  its  weaknesses.  Therefore,  recommendations  were  made  for  its  further  strengthening
and strategic growth. The major weaknesses are as follows. (i) Despite the commitment of SBV, its
resources are unable to cope with the rapid growth of PCFs, resulting in close supervision being
compromised,  as  of  June  2000,  the  license  of  about  28  PCFs  have  been  withdrawn  for  reasons
including  poor  management,  undercapitalization,  chronic  loan  arrears,  poor  deposit  mobilization,
poor location in areas with low business potential and some PCFs operated purely for profit instead
of also embracing the social economic objective of the Government. (ii) Some PCFs encountered
serious problems and risks by expanding too fast into neighboring commune. (iii) The physical and
business-supporting  facilities  of  the  PCFs  are  still  relatively  poor.  (iv)  The  network  is  still  not
efficiently integrated, resulting in delays in providing support services to PCFs like emergency call
for funds and deposit of excess funds. (v) PCFs at commune level are still fledgling and vulnerable.
Further measures to ensure their security and long-term survival are necessary.

17.
For  further  strengthening  and  strategic  growth  of  the  PCF  system,  the  comprehensive
review made these major recommendations: (i) 2000 will be the year for consolidating and further
strengthening  the  PCF  network;  no  new  PCF  will  be  established.  (ii)  The  legal  framework
governing  the  operation  of  the  PCF  network  will  be  further  studied  and  improved  to  address  the
concerns  raised  so  far,  e.g.,  clarification  of  the  rights  and  features  of  qualifying  and  permanent
shares,  legal  issues  on  foreclosure  proceedings,  and  the  legal  status  of  RCF.    (iii)  PCF  should
operate only within the confines of a commune. (iv) Strategic studies on the integrating model for
the  PCF  network  should  be  carried  out.    SBV  has  decided  that  a  two-tier  PCF  system  is  more
efficient than the present three-tier structure.  In this regard, CCF has been instructed to integrate
RCFs into its operations within a reasonable time frame. CCF has submitted a corporate plan up to
2001 to the Governor of SBV. In the plan, two new regional branches will be set up in Binh Dinh
and Nghe An provinces, which will help in managing RCFs eventually converted into branches of
CCF. SBV is now studying the cooperative bank model and the credit union model. (v) To expand
its banking services, PCF can act as agent of a commercial bank for providing funds and banking
services.  (vi)  CCF  will  be  empowered  to  manage  the  business  operations  of  the  entire  network,
which include managing liquidity and solvency, acting as clearinghouse for inter-PCF transactions,
carrying  out  internal  inspection  and  supervision,  managing  the  MIS,  and  reporting  to  SBV  and
concerned agencies. (vii) A security fund is proposed to be set up with contributions from member
PCFs.

External Assistance

22.
PCFs  are  currently  receiving  TA  from  the  Canadian  International  Development  Agency
(CIDA)  and  the  GTZ-DG  (Deutsche  Gesellschaft  für  Technische  Zusammenarbeit-Deutsche
Genossenschaftsbank)  Bank.  CIDA  has  provided  two  TA  projects  to  SBV.  Under  the  first  C$1.9
million1 TA project (3/1993 – 3/1997), the focus of the Desjardins Development International (DID)
consultants was to advise on the design and conceptual framework and the start–up process of the
PCF  network.  The  second  C$3.1  million  TA  project  (1997-2000)  focuses  on  consolidation  and
implementation of the PCF system.  The emphasis is on resolving any institutional and operational
issues  and  improving  operational  efficiencies.  CIDA  is  now  formulating  its  third  TA  project  for
assisting the network. This assistance may be in implementing the proposals made under its earlier
TA for improving accounting, training, reporting, and the MIS. The GTZ is providing DM3.5 million2
TA  (1999-2001)  to  the  network.  An  international  consultant  was  fielded  in  March  2000  for  the
duration of the TA. The focus of the assistance is on the structural integration of the PCF network,
training,  and  institutional  strengthening  through  improvement  in  operational  efficiencies.  The
ongoing assistance by CIDA and GTZ has been very useful to the PCF network.

23.
Under the Rural Credit Project, the CCF was provided a loan equivalent to $16.195 million
for two components: (i) a credit line for onlending to PCFs, and (ii) institutional strengthening. To
date, CCF has withdrawn $12 million (D150.694 billion) to finance 82,000 subprojects by PCFs. As
of 31 December 1999, accumulated subloans under the project amounted to D768 billion. Despite
many obstacles, the credit to the poor component equivalent to $2 million has been implemented
and 20,000 poor members have benefited so far.

24. With funds provided by Agence Internationale pour la Francophonie (AIF), CCF has since
1997  granted  medium-term  loans  (3  years)  to  women  who  are  owners  of  medium  and  small
enterprises.  Total  funds  supported  by  the  agency  aggregated  to  F650,0003  (over  D1.4  billion).
Statistics  show  that  500  new  jobs  have  been  created,  of  which  85  percent  were  for  women.  AIF
intends to continue assistance for expanding the project in other areas.

POVERTY AND GOVERNMENT REFORM STRATEGIES

A.

Economic Reform

1.
Economic  reforms  have  been  one  of  the  most  striking  features  of  Viet  Nam  during  the  past
decade. Substantive market-oriented reforms since 1989, among others, have led to (i) liberalization
of most price controls, (ii) significant reduction in subsidies and the State budget deficit, and (iii) the
decollectivization  of  agriculture.    A  new  constitution  supporting  the  shift  to  a  market  system  was
adopted in 1992.  Important legal reforms were also undertaken, including the promulgation of the (i)
Law on Private Enterprises (1990); (ii) Law on Companies (1990); (iii) Land Law (1993) giving farmers
land use rights; (iv) Labor Code (1994) protecting employer and employee rights and obligations; (v)
Bankruptcy Law establishing a legal framework for restructuring and liquidating insolvent enterprises;
(vi)  Civil  Code  (1995)  that  laid  the  legal  foundation  for  market  economy;  (vii)  Law  on  Cooperatives
(1996); (viii) Law on State Bank of Viet Nam (SBV) (1997); and (ix) Law on Credit Institutions (1997).

2.
The  reform  programs  have  substantially  restored  macroeconomic  stability,  permitting  an
accelerated  gross  domestic  product  (GDP)  growth  of  7-9  percent  over  the  last  seven  years  (1991-
1998), and attracted public and private foreign capital. The fiscal deficit has been curbed and inflation
has declined from 394 percent in 1988 to under 8 percent in 1999. In the last five years, poverty has
declined  dramatically.  Poverty  in  Viet  Nam  was  58  percent  in  1993  and  dropped  to  37  percent  in
1998.  The  number  below  the  food  poverty  line  has  also  declined  from  25  percent  in  1993  to  15
percent in 1998. In recent years, almost no other country has recorded a sharp decline in poverty in
such  a  short  period  of  time.  Although  poverty  has  declined,  this  situation  is  still  very  critical  in  rural
areas. For the banking sector, this has translated into increased security of long-term investment and
positive interest rates on savings. Predictably, both domestic savings and investment have picked up.
Growth in private sector investment and increases in employment accompanied this.

3.
The  financial  crisis  in  the  region,  however,  significantly  subdued  the  high  growth  rates  and
made  the  economy  susceptible  to  underlying  policy  weaknesses.  Recognizing  this,  the  Government
plans  to  undertake  further  reform  to  encourage  the  growth  and  diversification  of  the  private  sector.
Since  the  state  sector  continues  to  play  the  dominant  role  in  resource  allocation,  sustainable  and
rapid  economic growth still  depends  heavily on the quality of public sector investment and resource
allocation.    The  Government’s  priorities  (for  1996-2000)  as  outlined  by  the  Prime  Minister  in  the
National Assembly, are to (i) increase the competitiveness and efficiency of the economy, (ii) intensify
the  reform  of  State-owned  enterprises  (SOEs),  (iii)  modernize  and  streamline  the  financial  and
banking sector, (iv) ensure the social and environmental sustainability of economic growth, (v) deepen
public administration reform, and (vi) foster rural development and industrialization.

4.
In the banking sector, the remnants of the command economy mean that investment credit is
very scarce, banks have little experience in term lending and often feel unnecessarily exposed, and
credit  staff  in  the  State-owned  commercial  banks  (SOCBs)  after  years  of  lending  to  SOEs  are
untrained and unused to dealing with the private sector. The retraining of staff to equip them with the
skills necessary to appraise and manage credits to private businesses is a priority for both Viet Nam
Bank for Agriculture and Rural Development (VBARD) and central people’s credit fund-people’s credit
funds.1  The  products  that  suit  micro,  small  and  medium-scale  businesses  best  -  investment  loans,
equipment  leasing,  and  overdrafts  -  are  not  readily  available.  New  product  development  is  an
important  area  for  the  banks.2  Recent  relaxation  of  the  collateral  requirements  by  SBV  so  that  land
use  rights  and  assets  purchased  with  loan  proceeds  can  be  used  as  collateral  have  given  small
borrowers  access  to  term  credit,  but  the  new  regulation  needs  to  be  brought  into  practice  by  the

                                                

1  Under the Project provision is made for extensive training for both VBARD and central people’s credit fund-people’s credit

funds in credit appraisal and micro and small business loan management.

2  VBARD  is  being  assisted  with  new  product  and  service  development  under  TA  3227-VIE:Strengthening Corporate

Governance at VBARD, for $900,000, approved on 19 July 1999.

 56

Appendix 5, page 2

banks. Lending to SOEs continues to use a large amount of SOCB resources. Although VBARD has
reduced the share of SOE lending from about 60 to about 30 percent of its outstanding portfolio over
the last five years, one-half of all new loans still go to SOEs, effectively rationing credit for the private
sector.

B.

Poverty

5.
There  are  different  measures  of  poverty,  and  according  to  each  definition,  Viet  Nam  has  a
different  poverty  rate.  For  the  Project  the  definitions  of  the  World  Bank  and  the  Viet  Nam  General
Statistical  Office  (GSO)  are  used.  As  defined,  households  on  the  food  poverty  line  have  per  capita
consumption of less than 2,100 calories per day, but no allowance for essential nonfood expenditure.
Food security was equal to $92 or D1,278,000 per year in 1998. A higher poverty line, which includes
expenditure for other essential nonfood needs, is equal to $128 or D1,790,000 per capita per year.

6.
The incidence of rural poverty (44.9 percent of the rural population) is five times that of urban
poverty (9.0 percent). Over 90 percent of the poor are still in rural areas. Poverty has declined since
1993,  but  the  difference  between  urban  and  rural  areas  has  increased  (Table  A5.1).  In  1998,  the
highest  incidences  of  poverty  were  59  percent  in  the  northern  uplands,  52  percent  in  the  central
highlands  and  48  percent  in  the  north  central  coastal  region  (Table  A5.2).  The  lowest  incidence  of
poverty  was  in  the  South  East  at  8  percent.  Since  1993,  the  Red  River  delta  achieved  the  biggest
reduction  in  poverty,  and  the  Mekong  River  delta  the  lowest.  Among  the  three  poorest  regions,  the
north central coast has seen the greatest reduction and the northern upland the least. Poverty is most
prevalent in the uplands the northern mountains and the central highlands.

7.
Most of the poor in 1998 were farmers (79 percent) or workers in agriculture. Falling poverty in
Viet  Nam  has  been  associated  with  falling  poverty  rates  within  each  occupational  category,  rather
than  shifts  in  occupational  patterns  (Table  A5.3).  The  poor  have  relatively  low  levels  of  educational
attainment,  and  lack  functional  skills  and  information.  Ninety  percent  of  the  poor  have  had  lower
secondary school or lower. The incidence of poverty is highest (57 percent) for those who have not

 57

Appendix 5, page 3

even  completed  primary  education.  By  contrast,  there  is  hardly  any  poverty  among  those  with  a
university  degree  (4  percent)  (Table  A5.4).  Households  with  many  children  are  often  poorer.  The
number  of  children  is  highest  in  households  in  the  poorest  quintile  (2.8  for  the  lowest  quintile)  and
drops as per capita expenditure rises. The poor have less access to material resources such as land,
credit;  less  access  to  social  and  physical  infrastructure;  are  vulnerable  to  shocks–illness,  business
crisis and natural disaster–and feel uncertain about their future. Three groups of poor households are
especially susceptible: ethnic minority groups, unregistered migrants in urban areas, and children.

Table A5.3: Total Poverty in Different Occupations, 1998

Source: GSO and WB estimation based on VLSS93 and VLSS98, in WB, 1999, p. 18.

8.
The doi moi (renovation) policies initiated in the late 1980s have led to rapid growth in GDP.
Between  1992  and  1998,  agricultural  GDP  grew  by  4.5  percent,  industrial  GDP  by  13  percent,  and
GDP in the service sector by 8.3 percent. During this period, the main source of poverty reduction has
been  from  agricultural  diversification.  On-farm  employment  has  grown  very  little  (the  share  of
agricultural  unemployment  declined  by  5  percent,  from  71  percent  to  66  percent),  but  agricultural
incomes  rose  dramatically  by  61  percent.  The  living  standards  of  rural  households  have  improved
dramatically  during  this  period.  However,  agriculture  may  not  be  able  to  grow  as  fast  in  the  future.
Hence, off-farm employment and off-farm activities will need to play a relatively more important role in
poverty reduction.
