9.
To date, Viet Nam has yet to achieve dramatic growth in rural nonfarm employment. In 1993-
1998, the percentage of rural households with at least one nonfarm enterprise remained stagnant at
around  40  percent.  The  nonfarm  enterprises  of  Viet  Nam  are  still  dominated  by  retailing  and  food
processing, which accounted for 34 percent and 12 percent of all nonfarm rural enterprises in 1998.
Income from nonfarm enterprises grew by a solid 31 percent. As a result, household income derived
from agriculture went from 37 to 47 percent, that from household non-enterprises remained more or
less the same at about 19 percent, while that from wages and other sources declined from 44 to 34
percent.  There  is  enormous  potential  for  non-farm  enterprises  to  play  a  more  prominent  role  in

 58

Appendix 5, page 4

generating  employment  and  incomes  for  Viet  Nam's  future  development  to  absorb  much  of  the
surplus  labor  in  agriculture.  However,  this  sector  faces  capital  shortage  and  resource  management
capacity and skills.

10.
There has been an increase in inequality nation-wide between urban and rural areas, between
regions, and within each region (Table A5.5).  Poor households often express a sense of alienation
from decision-making processes and feel ill informed about government policies and programs. Often
it is the better-off households who know more about government services and how to access them.
People want to be consulted and question top-down policies, such as on compulsory taxes, fees, and
contributions. The Viet Nam Living Standard Survey (VLSS) data showed that the level and incidence
of taxes, fees, and contributions vary significantly between regions and provinces (Table A5.6) giving
rise  to  accusations  of  lack  of  transparency  and  accountability  in  the  way  that  taxes  and  fees  are
collected and spent.

11.
Although  there  is  a  mechanism  to  feed  information  down  to  the  village  level,  this  does  not
always  work  well.  In  many  cases,  the  processes  in  place  do  not  allow  the  poor  households  to
communicate  their  concerns  and  priorities  back  up  through  the  system.  However,  the  Government
has  recognized  the  need  for  reorienting  Government  planning  supporting  and  complementing
individual  involvement  in  economic  decision  making  at  the  grassroot  level.  Toward  this  end  the
Grassroots Democracy Decree (Decree No. 29, issued in May 1998) is an initiative that provides an
opportunity to improve the transparency of local government operation and to provide households with
more information about local government activities and finances.  Nevertheless, the decree is still in
the early stages of implementation.

 59

Appendix 5, page 5

Rural households have limited access to reliable facilities for saving, which could be withdrawn
12.
in  times  of  hardship  or  peak  expenditure.  This  limits  the  ability  of  poor  households  to  cope  with
shocks.  Public  safety  nets  and  targeted  programs  to  help  the  poor  have  been  implemented  in  Viet
Nam.  The  Government's  Hunger  Eradication  and  Poverty  Reduction  (HEPR)  program  provides  a
framework  to  address  some  of  the  most  pressing  needs  of  poor  households.  However,  it  is  not  yet
clear what impact these policies and programs have had on the poor.

13.
Although Viet Nam has made considerable progress in reducing poverty in the last five years,
poverty  remains  widespread  and  deep.  Labor  is  commonly  regarded  as  the  poor's  most  abundant
asset.  To  raise  the  living  standards  of  the  able-bodied  poor,  it  is  essential  to  provide  them  with  the
opportunities  for  productive  and  remunerative  employment.  Hence,  the  three  engines  of  growth-
agricultural growth and diversification, rural off-farm employment, and urban employment - that have
led  to  poverty  reduction  during  1993-1998  should  continue  to  become  the  engines  of  growth  in  the
coming  years.  Stimulating  off-farm  employment  and  urban  employment  growth  is  a  major  challenge
and  will  require  a  host  of  reforms,  including  equal  opportunities  with  the  State  sector,  removing
constraints  to  capital  access,  establishing  a  reliable  legal  framework,  and  providing  supporting
infrastructure.  Ensuring  that  agricultural  development  contributes  fully  to  rural  income  growth  and
poverty  reduction  in  the  future  requires  a  number  of  key  actions:  (i)  reforms  to  further  liberalize  the
agriculture  sector  should  be  continued  and  deepened;  (ii)  Viet  Nam’s  land  law  needs  to  be  fully
implemented;  (iii)  rural  finance  needs  to  be  overhauled  in  the  context  of  overall  banking  reform;  (iv)
investments  need  to  focus  on  rural  infrastructure;  (v)  agricultural  research  and  extension  system  to
help  farmers  should  be  focused,  client-oriented,  and  better  allocated,  with  the  private  sector
encouraged to play a role in this field; and (vi) water resource should be well managed and efficient.

C.

Promoting Rural Enterprise

14.
The  Project  focuses  on  providing  assistance  to  the  nonfarm  business  activities  of  micro  and
small  businesses  including  non-SOEs,  cooperatives,  registered  household  enterprises,  and  other
household businesses that are not registered in rural areas. There is no official definition of micro and
small enterprises (MSE) in Viet Nam. Under decision No. 681/CP-KTN of 20 June 1998, a small and
medium-scale  enterprise  (SME)  is  defined  as  an  incorporated  enterprise  with  less  than  D5  billion  in
capital and employing less than 200 persons. For the purposes of the Project, micro enterprises are
defined as businesses typically having less than five employees and small enterprises are defined as
typically having less than 50 employees. Nonfarm businesses are businesses that are not concerned
with  primary  agricultural,  livestock,  and  forestry  production.  Non-SOEs  comprise  joint-stock
companies,  limited-liability  companies,  and  sole  proprietorships  incorporated  under  the  Companies
Law and the Law on Private Enterprises and approved by the relevant Provincial People’s Committee
or higher level authority. A cooperative is an enterprise incorporated under the Law on Co-operatives.
Household enterprises are predominantly nonfarm business under a business licence granted by the
District People’s Committee in accordance with Decree 66-HDBT of 1992.  Household businesses are
nonfarm businesses that are not registered as part of households’ overall farm and nonfarm activities.
Rural  areas  are  defined  as  areas  outside  the  municipal  boundaries  of  major  cities.  Collectively,  the
businesses to be supported under the project are referred to as rural nonfarm businesses.

15.
The private sector has grown rapidly from a negligible base since the promulgation in 1991 of
the  Law  on  Private  Enterprises  and  the  Law  on  Companies.  In  1999  there  were  386  joint-stock
companies,  11,742  limited-liability  companies,  and  26,338  registered  household  businesses.  The
cooperative  sector  collapsed  in  the  early  1990s,  with  numbers  falling  from  nearly  43,000  in  1989  to
only  1,876  in  1995.  Subsequently  there  has  been  some  revival  and  in  1998  there  were  4,259
nonagricultural  cooperatives.  The  most  recent  estimate  of  the  number  of  unregistered  household
businesses  is  2.22  million  in  1996.3  The  number  of  SOEs  fell  from  about  12,000  in  1990  to  about

STATUS OF THE RURAL CREDIT PROJECT

A. 

Objectives, Scope, and Rationale

The  Rural  Credit  Project  (RCP)1  was  to  strengthen  the  Viet  Nam  Bank  for  Agriculture  and
1.
Rural Development (VBARD) and the People’s Credit Fund (PCF) and supplementing their medium-
and  long-term  resources  in  financing  viable  small-  and  medium-scale  agriculture-related  enterprises
for which there was a large potential in the rural areas. The objectives were to (i) increase the income
of rural people and expand productive employment by providing short- and medium- term credit to the
rural sector; and (ii) strengthen the rural financial system, thereby improving financial services to the
rural  sector.  As  envisaged,  the  RCP  was  implemented  throughout  the  country  except  in  urbanized
provinces. It comprised three components: (i) a credit line ($43 million) to VBARD ($29.4 million) and
the Central People’s Credit Fund (CCF) ($13.6 million); (ii) strengthening of financial institutions ($2.0
million).  VBARD  ($0.69  million),  PCFs  ($0.96  million),  and  International  Credit  Project  Management
Unit (ICPMU) ($0.35 million); and (iii) strengthening project management of ICPMU of the State Bank
of  Viet  Nam  (SBV)  ($0.94  million).  The  financial  institutions  were  strengthened  through  training  and
support facilities financed from the loan. In addition to the institutional strengthening component under
the Project, the Asian Development Bank (ADB) provided VBARD with technical assistance in 1999 to
strengthen its corporate governance.2

B.  

Cost, Financing and Implementation Status

2.
The total cost of the RCP was estimated at $75.8 million equivalent, of which $25 million was
the  foreign  exchange  cost  and  $50.8  million  equivalent  the  local  currency  cost.  ADB’s  loan  of  $50
million  from  the  Asian  Development  Fund  (ADF)  resources  was  to  finance  all  the  foreign  exchange
cost equivalent to 33 percent of the total cost and 49 percent of the local cost equivalent to 33 percent
of the total cost, while the participating financial institutions and the subborrowers were to finance all
51 percent of the local currency cost and 34 percent of the total cost, respectively.

3.
Implementation of the RCP commenced after the loan became effective in April 1997.  It was
expected that the RCP would provide subloans for about 100,000 subprojects and that the loan would
be  committed  within  three  years  and  disbursed  within  four  years  of  loan  effectiveness.  As  of  29
February 2000, the RCP had provided subloans for a total of 124,500 subprojects and disbursement
under the loan stood at $43 million. The commitments and disbursements exceeded the expectations
at  appraisal  and  only  $2  million3  remained  to  be  disbursed  for  institutional  strengthening.  It  was
expected that the loan will be fully disbursed by end of 2000.

4.
The  RCP  was  implemented  in  line  with  the  arrangements  envisaged  at  appraisal.  The  loan
covenants  were  generally  well  conceived  and  appropriate.  In  particular,  the  covenant  requiring  a
repayment  performance  of  at  least  80  percent  ensured  that  VBARD  and  the  PCFs  took  care  in
selecting subborrowers and subprojects. To date, the level of compliance with covenants by VBARD
and  the  PCFs  has  been  fairly  satisfactory.  Particularly  noteworthy  are  the  1997  and  1998  recovery
rates  of  over  95  percent.  The  reported  recovery  rate  for  1999  is  98  percent.  The  allocation  of  $2
million for lending to the poor by PCFs was delayed and only implemented in 1999. The prescribed
subloan size of $20 to $100 made it unattractive to PCFs to lend and was also too small for the poor.
The loan covenant, which specifies a lending rate from Government to the PFIs of at least ADB’s rate
for  OCR  was  inappropriate  and  would  have  immobilized  the  Project  if  early  actions  to  rationalize  it
were not taken by the Government. The current rate is based on the weighted average cost of deposit

63

funds of the financial system determined every quarter or as frequently as SBV feels it is necessary.
Also  inappropriate  was  the  requirement  that  the  participating  financial  institutions  (PFIs)  have  to
borrow funds at commercial rates to finance institutional strengthening. These loan conditions partly
caused the delay in implementing the component and was resolved when the Government, PMU and
PFIs  agreed  that  loan  funds  would  be  provided  at  ADB’s  ADF  rate.  Some  delays  occurred  in
implementing  environment-related  aspects  of  the  subprojects.  Although  VBARD  and  the  PCFs
integrated environmental considerations in their subloan appraisals, the appreciation of environment
safeguards and actual implementation by subborrowers is, in many cases, still lacking. The PFIs are
now  working  to  overcome  these  deficiencies.  It  has  also  been  noted  that  the  high  demand  for  rural
enterprise financing has put undue pressure on VBARD and the PCFs field appraisal staff. Each staff
member  manages  more  than  800  subloans  (including  those  for  nonproject  credit),  resulting  in  weak
supervision  of  subloans.  However,  such  weak  supervision  has  not  affected  repayment  performance
because  the  PFIs  (especially  VBARD)  have  a  system  of  performance-based  remuneration  that
penalizes staff who fail to meet the target for subloan recovery. This policy is unfair to the staff and
VBARD is currently reviewing it. With the expansion in project lending, the PFIs have to rationalize the
workload  of  field  staff  in  the  interest  of  ensuring  sufficient  supervision  of  subprojects  and
subborrowers’ compliance with applicable loan covenants.

C. 

Preliminary Evaluation of Initial Performance

1.

Overall Lending

5.
A  comprehensive  midterm  review  of  the  RCP  was  carried  out  jointly  by  SBV,  VBARD,  CCF,
and  ADB  in  year  3  of  implementation.  A  domestic  consultant  firm  was  recruited  to  undertake  a
socioeconomic  survey  and  to  evaluate  the  implementation  of  the  RCP.  The  consultant  used  the
participatory  rural  assessment  (PRA)  approach  and  supported  it  with  secondary  data  review.  Under
the  PRA,  a  sample  of  1,380  households  (900  households  were  borrowers  and  480  were
nonborrowers).  These  households  were  randomly  selected  in  15  provinces  on  the  basis  of  several
criteria,  among  them,  outstanding  loans  (high  and  low),  regional  representation,  geographic
representation  (highland  and  lowland),  presence  of  PFI  branches.  Fifteen  VBARD  branches  and  15
PCFs in these 15 provinces were then randomly selected.

The survey found that (i) impact on PFIs is positive, especially in respect of promoting a more
6.
balanced source and application of term resources, adoption of international practices in finance and
banking,  a  better  appreciation  of  the  concepts  of  sustainability  as  it  relates  to  profitability  and
environment; (ii) economic impact on subborrowers is significant, including better access to term loan
funds,  diversification  of  income-generating  activities  from  farm  to  off-farm  rural  enterprises,  and
increased income; (iii) social impacts on beneficiaries are also significant, comprising, among others,
a  greater  awareness  of  environmental  impacts,  reduction  of  borrowing  from  money-lenders  and
middlemen, improved credit literacy, increased participation of social organization and local people’s
committees in lending decisions of PFIs and in recovery of loans, and increased sensitivity to gender
issues and education.

2.

Lending under the Rural Credit Project

7.

billion,  with  an  average  loan  size  of  D5.5  million.  In  the  case  of  VBARD,  43.6  percent  of  subloans
were  made  in  the  northern  upland,  7.7  percent  to  the  Red  River  delta,  21.5  percent  to  the  north-

southeast, and 13.5 percent to the Mekong River delta.

8.
The  data  in  the  tables  indicate  that  subloans  were  made  for  various  purposes.  In  total,  52
percent  (77.5  percent  by  number)  went  to  capital  investments  in  agricultural  production  activities,
livestock, and aquaculture, while the rest were for agroprocessing and support services. Comparatively,
VBARD made more loans for crop production, livestock, and aquaculture (86 percent by amount), while
PCFs  made  only  59  percent  of  total  loans  by  amount  to  these  sectors.    PCFs  made  more  loans  for
agroprocessing and support services.

In  terms  of  socioeconomic  characteristics,  subborrowers  were  from  low-income  groups.  The
9.
average household size was 5.2, of which an average of 3.2 were in the work force. VBARD and PCFs
subborrowers were mainly low-income clients with more than 70 percent having an annual income of
less than D2 million. Eighty percent had a main income from agriculture or aquaculture, while the rest
earned  their  main  income  from  services  and  other  agriculture-related  activities.  The  subloans  made
ranged  from  D500,000  to  D7  million  and  averaged  D6  million.  More  than  85  percent  of  the
subborrowers were between 25 and 50 years old; 90 percent had gone beyond primary education, with
65  percent  finishing  secondary  or  vocational  schooling.  About  7  percent  of  respondents  hired  labor
while 30 percent hired as well as maximized use of family labor, and 60 percent used only family labor.
Eighty-five  percent  of  hired  labor  was  women.  On  average,  one  full  job  was  created  for  a  subloan
investment  of  $650.  Seventy  percent  of  the  respondents  reported  that  the  decision  to  borrow  was  a
family decision, while 5 percent said that the wife made the decision. In 100 percent of the cases, both
husband  and  wife  signed  the  loan  application.    More  than  60  percent  of  the  respondents  were  new
borrowers  of  VBARD  or  PCFs.  They  either  have  not  borrowed  before  or  have  been  borrowing  from
moneylenders, relatives, and friends. Seventy percent of the respondents complained that the subloan
amount  was  insufficient  and  that  they  took  additional  loans  from  other  sources.  Ninety  percent  of  the
respondents claim a significant change in income because of the loan.

B. 

Credit Models

2.
Sixteen of these model businesses covering the whole of the investment range were chosen
for  more  detailed  analysis.  A  summary  of  the  results  is  presented  in  Table  A9.2.  The  analyzed
subprojects  have  cost-benefit  ratios  at  a  12  percent  discount  rate  ranging  from  1.04  to  1.29,  and
financial internal rates of return of between 14 and 56 percent. The sensitivity analysis on reduction in
sales prices and increases in costs shows that all businesses can withstand 5 percent cost increases
or  5  percent  sales  price  reductions,  and  the  majority  of  the  subprojects  remained  viable  with  10
percent cost  increases or  10  percent sales reductions. The exceptions  are subprojects that process
commodities in bulk or rely on volume output and are  characterized by low value added. However,
such businesses are normally able to adjust to price changes with the market, and can be expected to
maintain their viability.

3.
The  subproject  analyses  use  a  standardized  set  of  assumptions  to  make  subprojects
comparable.  The  project  life  is  taken  as  the  life  of  the  main  investment  asset.  Capital  costs  are
depreciated  on  a  straight-line  basis  over  the  life  of  the  assets  involved,  and  residual  values  added
back  to  the  cash  flow  in  the  last  year.  Working  capital  is  taken  as  a  proportion  of  operating  costs
before  taxes,  varying  from  one  week  to  six  months  depending  on  the  nature  of  the  project  and  the
resources that are tied up in production at one time. Labor is priced at D10,000 per day for unskilled
workers, D20,000 to D25,000 per day for skilled workers, depending on the skill level required. Taxes
are calculated at a standard 32 percent of profit before tax. Foreign exchange percentages are based
on the cost of imported items or imported components adjusted for local margins and sales taxes and
a component of the working capital for items in operating costs that are imported.

4.
Analysis of the models shows an average foreign exchange cost of 45 percent for the range of
subprojects  that  will  be  financed  by  VBARD  and  40  percent  for  subprojects  that  will  be  financed  by
PCFs.

C. 

Employment Creation and Income Generation

5.
Analysis of employment creation shows that subprojects on average will create 2.91 full-time
job equivalents while those requiring subloans of less than $10,000 will create 1.95 jobs on average.
However,  these  figures  are  inflated  by  the  inclusion  of  four  subprojects  with  unusually  high
employment  potential  (furniture  production,  rice  cake  manufacture  and  roof  tile  manufacture).  When
these projects are removed from the analysis, the average employment creation effects are 1.8 full-
time  equivalent  jobs  for  all  subprojects  and  1.3  full-time  equivalent  jobs  for  subloans  less  than
$10,000. These more conservative figures are used in the estimation of employment generation. It is
expected that about 32,900 subloans by PCFs of less than $10,000 will create about 51,900 jobs and
about 38,400 subloans by VBARD will create about a further 49,800 jobs, bringing the total to about
101,700  new  jobs  of  which  about  73,100  will  be  in  low-income  households  and  20,200  in  micro
businesses.

6.
For  all  projects,  the  average  cost  per  job  created  is  $3,840  and  for  investment  requiring
subloans of less than $10,000 is $996. Removing the high employment generation activities from the
analysis, the average cost per job created is $6,785 for all subprojects, and for subprojects needing
subloans of less than $10,000 it is $2,118 (Table A9.2).

Overall  in  1999,  VBARD  provided  about  $22.9  million  in  new  term  credit  for  rural  industry  and
14.
trade and services, and a further $169 million in new short-term credit in these sectors. Total new lending
was $191.9 million. VBARD has increased its term lending progressively from 23 percent of its portfolio
in  1995  to  39  percent  in  1999  and  has  gained  substantial  experience  in  term  lending  over  this  period.
About  26  percent  (D2,004  billion  or  $143  million)  of  the  total  outstanding  term  loans  of  D7,845  billion
($560 million) was funded from external credit lines at the end of 1999.

2. 

PCFs

16.
In  1999,  PCFs  provided  credit  to  about  746,000  households  to  a  total  value  of  D3,617  billion
(about $258 million) with an average loan size of D4.8 million ($343). About 150,000 of these households
are  poor  households.  Most  PCF  loans  are  short-term  loans  of  1-10  months  duration  with  an  average
maturity  of  3-6  months.  The  portfolio  is  diversified.  In  1999,  57  percent  of  lending  was  for  agricultural
activities (about D2,062 billion or $147 million), 28 percent for services and trade (about D1,013 billion or
$72  million),  12  percent  for  rural  industries  (about  D434  billion  or  $31  million),  and  the  remaining  3
percent for consumption purposes (about D108 billion of $8 million). The total lending for agroprocessing
and  other  rural  businesses  excluding  farming  is  estimated  to  have  been  about  D1,447  billion  ($103
million) in 1999. PCFs have been reluctant to give term credit until now because of a shortage of term
deposits and a desire to have matched maturities.

3. 

Demand

For  the  industry  sector,  World  Bank  projections1  of  gross  domestic  product  (GDP)  estimate  a
17.
minimum of 5.8 percent growth in 2000, 9 percent in 2001, and 8.8 percent in 2002, 2.7 percent in the
service sector in 2000. For the service sector the projections are 2.7 percent in 2000, 5.1 in 2001 and 4.9
in  2002.  If  VBARD  and  PCFs  respond  only  to  the  increases  in  demand  that  will  result  from  projected
GDP growth, then the new lending would be $634.5 million for VBARD and $340.6 million for PCFs over
this  period.  The  proposed  ADB  credit  lines  of  about  $35  million  for  VBARD  and  $10  million  for  PCFs
would provide 5.5 and 2.9 percent, respectively, of this lending.

18.
However, not only is it likely that the private sector will continue to grow in relative terms, fueled in
part by the equitization and privatization of state-owned enterprises, but there is strong evidence that the
effective demand for loan capital from micro, small, and medium-scale enterprises is unsatisfied, offering
greater potential for VBARD and PCFs to expand their lending, particularly for term loans. Recent studies
show that the largest constraint to private enterprise development in Viet Nam is that of term capital.  2
Aware  of  this,  both  VBARD  and  CCF-PCF  wish  to  develop  long-term  financing.  In  VBARD’s  case,  the
proportion of term financing in the portfolio can be expected to continue to grow, but less rapidly than in
the last five years; in the case of PCFs, rapid growth can be expected with the first availability to them of
funds for term lending to nonfarm businesses under the ADB loan.
                                                

1  World Bank. 1999. Vietnam, Preparing for Take-off? Hanoi.
2  Nomura Research Institute (1999) in Study on the Promotion of Small and Medium-Scale Enterprises in Viet Nam from a
survey of SMEs reports that loans to SMEs are nearly always restricted to short-term credit for working capital and medium-
term funds are very scarce and difficult to access. The Stockholm School of Economics (1998) in Anatomy and Dynamics of
Small-scale  Private  Manufacturing  in  Viet  Nam  studied  over  500  enterprises  and  found  funding  shortage  was  the  most
serious  constraint  to  growth  in  these  enterprises.  The  Mekong  Project  Development  Facility  (1999)  in  Viet  Nam’s
Undersized  Engine:  a  Survey  of  95  Larger  Private  Manufacturers  (with  less  than  100  employees)  found  that  53  percent
cited  difficulty  In  reply  to:  accessing  investment  capital  as  a  major  constraint  to  their  development,  while  39  percent  said
working  capital  access  was  also  a  major  difficulty.  CIEM-UNIDO  (1998)  in  Improving  the  Macroeconomic  Policy  and
Reforming  the  Administrative  Procedures  to  Promote  the  Development  the  Small  and  Medium  Enterprises  in  Viet  Nam
found that 55 percent of enterprises had difficulty in accessing investment and working capital.
